And if you can tell the AI, hey, you can give me multiple tools to use at once, I think that's going to unlock different applications than before. Because before it was just like, okay, this is a task, tell me one tool and what's the input for it. But if the AI can now use multiple tools in parallel... you can first of all have more specialized tools. And then get more specialized instructions for each tool. Yeah. It's just going to unlock a lot of cool applications that previously weren't possible."

[01:22:32] "The whole creating of an assistant and running that through an assistant is today's support. You can do that literally right now... From first message to second message... we can just see the funnel, where, if it's faster, the code runs faster... Of course there's vision stuff, there's code interpreter as a tool in the API. But, I think what will bring the most applications is actually the, the speed. Because there are so many things, if you look at our numbers, users are not patient. They want an answer, and they want an answer quick."

[02:14:28] "As a founder, or as, so, who's the audience? Is it like, other founders, or is it? Other founders, and people are just interested in how you are, you're processing this... What I'll tell them is, Man, so many people give up before even getting started. And that happens a lot. Don't do that. Sure you can change your idea. You can find new things to work on. But... To get something to work properly, it takes some effort. How I'm processing it?... It's like risk, right? If you, if you want to build a risk-free startup, you probably don't want to work on startups... So I'm having so much fun. The way I'm thinking about this is like, whoa, there's all these new different things I could do now. I could build. That's so exciting to me. And I'm pumped."

title: Beating GPT-4 with Open Source LLMs ‚Äî with Michael Royzen of Phind
author: Michael Royzen
intro: At the  AI Pioneers Summit  we announced  Latent Space Launchpad , an AI-focused accelerator in partnership with  Decibel . If you‚Äôre an AI founder of enterprise early adopter, fill out  this form  and we‚Äôll be in touch with more details.  We also have a lot of events coming up as we wrap up the year, so make sure to check out our  community events  page and come say hi! We previously interviewed the founders of many developer productivity startups embedded in the IDE, like  Codium AI ,  Cursor , and  Codeium . We also covered  Replit‚Äôs (former) SOTA model , replit-code-v1-3b and most recently had Amjad and Michele announce  replit-code-v1_5-3b at the AI Engineer Summit . Much has been  speculated  about the StackOverflow traffic drop since ChatGPT release, but the experience is still not perfect. There‚Äôs now a new player in the ‚Äúsearch for developers‚Äù arena:  Phind . Phind‚Äôs goal is to help you find answers to your technical questions, and then help you implement them. For example  ‚ÄúWhat should I use to create a frontend for a Python script?‚Äù  returns a list of frameworks as well as links to the sources. You can then ask follow up questions on specific implementation details, having it write some code for you, etc. They have both a web version and a  VS Code integration They recently were  top of Hacker News  with the announcement of their latest model, which is now the #1 rated model on the  BigCode Leaderboard , beating their previous version: TLDR Cheat Sheet: * Based on CodeLlama-34B, which is trained on 500B tokens * Further fine-tuned on 70B+ high quality code and reasoning tokens * Expanded context window to 16k tokens * 5x faster than GPT-4 (100 tok/s vs 20 tok/s on single stream) * 74.7% HumanEval vs 45% for the base model We‚Äôve talked before about HumanEval being limited in a lot of cases and how it needs to be complemented with  ‚Äúvibe based‚Äù evals . Phind thinks of evals alongside two axis:  *  Context quality : when asking the model to generate code, was the context high quality? Did we put outdated examples in it? Did we retrieve the wrong files? *  Result quality:  was the code generated correct? Did it follow the instructions I gave it or did it misunderstand some of it? If you have bad results with bad context, you might get to a good result by working on better RAG. If you have good context and bad result you might either need to work on your prompting or you have hit the limits of the model, which leads you to fine tuning (like they did).  Michael was really early to this space and started working on CommonCrawl filtering and indexing back in 2020, which led to a lot of the insights that now power Phind. We talked about that evolution, his experience at YC, how he got Paul Graham to invest in Phind and invite him to dinner at his house, and how Ron Conway connected him with Jensen Huang to get access to more GPUs! Show Notes *  Phind *  BigScience T0 *  InstructGPT Paper *  Inception-V3 *  LMQL *  Marginalia Nu *  Mistral AI * People: *  Paul Graham  (pg) *  Ron Conway *  Yacine Jernite  from HuggingFace *  Jeff Delaney
timestamps: * [00:00:00] Intros & Michael's early interest in computer vision * [00:03:14] Pivoting to NLP and natural language question answering models * [00:07:20] Building a search engine index of Common Crawl and web pages * [00:11:26] Releasing the first version of Hello based on the search index and BigScience T0 model * [00:14:02] Deciding to focus the search engine specifically for programmers * [00:17:39] Overview of Phind's current product and focus on code reasoning * [00:21:51] The future vision for Phind to go from idea to complete code * [00:24:03] Transitioning to using the GPT-4 model and the impact it had * [00:29:43] Developing the Phind model based on CodeLlama and additional training * [00:32:28] Plans to continue improving the Phind model with open source technologies * [00:43:59] The story of meeting Paul Graham and Ron Conway and how that impacted the company * [00:53:02] How Ron Conway helped them get GPUs from Nvidia * [00:57:12] Tips on how Michael learns complex AI topics * [01:01:12] Lightning Round
ai_summary:
The "Latent Space Podcast" episode features a conversation between hosts Alessio and Swyx, and their guest, Michael Royzen from Phind. The episode kicks off with introductions and a brief discussion about recording in San Francisco during a hot October while the Blue Angels fly overhead. Michael shares his journey from being a high school entrepreneur who founded SmartLens, a computer vision startup in 2017, to his current venture, Phind. 

He discusses the technical evolution and motivation behind SmartLens, driven by the release of TensorFlow, the deep learning revolution, and improvements in computer vision models. Michael's interest in deep learning was sparked by an Apple WWDC conference he attended as a student scholar, leading him to create a model capable of recognizing a wide variety of objects running efficiently on iPhones without internet connectivity. 

SmartLens gained some attention, including a feature in TechCrunch, though its usage eventually tapered off. Despite this, it still maintains a user base that pays for the service through a subscription model, even without requiring server support. Further exploration into AI and deep learning led Michael to delve into natural language processing (NLP) and develop enterprise products, drawing him closer to Hugging Face and the world of transformer models.

Michael's path took a pivotal turn towards creating Phind after being inspired by various advancements in AI, including the integration of retrieval models with large language models (LLMs) for internet-scale question-answering systems. Phind has been developed as a system for programmers, aimed at providing accurate answers and solutions by processing extensive amounts of data and leveraging the latest AI models. The product has evolved to include various interfaces such as a web platform and a VS Code extension, catering to a broad spectrum of programming queries and challenges.

Throughout the podcast, insights into the founding story, technical breakthroughs, and the user-centric approach of Phind are shared, alongside discussions on future potential and the impact of AI on programming and problem-solving.
key_insights:
1. The transition from LLMs being glorified summarization models to powerful reasoning engines happened much faster than anticipated.
2. Prioritizing solving hallucinations in AI models is crucial for applications that need completely correct answers, like coding.
3. Exploring reinforcement learning for correctness rather than just avoiding harmfulness could be a significant advancement.
4. There's interest in more structured ways to evaluate LLM outputs to distinguish the sources of error effectively.
5. Applied research is merging with product development at Phind to utilize the latest AI techniques for a better search and reasoning product.
6. There's an exploration of formal grammars to restrict and modify model's decoding strategies to conform to specific grammars for improved correctness.
7. The integration of local models and hardware optimizations, like quantization and NVIDIA's FP8 implementation, is being explored for efficient local model running.
8. There's potential in developing a more structured prompting language or markup for more precise interactions with LLMs.
9. The origins of startup ideas should stem from deeply impactful insights or revelations that speak to founders on a meaningful level.
quotes:
1. **Michael Royzen on the importance of addressing real user needs through technical innovation** (timecode not provided): "I didn't even talk to users or do any of those things that you're supposed to do. I was just mainly interested in building a type of backend I've never built before."
   
2. **On leveraging advancements in natural language processing for practical applications** (timecode not provided): "It absolutely blew my mind... You could just ask a model a question, provide no extra context, and it would know what to do and just give you the answer."

3. **On iterative development and learning from user feedback** (timecode not provided): "But for the first time, it was working reasonably well... And that was the very first iteration of Hello. So I ended up doing a show HN on Hacker News in January 2022 of that system. Our fine tune T0 model connected to our Elasticsearch index... And I think that's the first example that I'm aware of a LLM search engine model that's effectively connected to like a large enough index that I consider like an internet scale."

4. **Michael on the evolutionary path of AI technologies and addressing complex problems** (timecode not provided): "And so we've optimized everything that we do for that. And that's a big reason of why we've built Phind specifically for programmers, as opposed to saying like, you know, we're kind of a search engine for everyone because as these models get more capable, we're very interested in seeing kind of what the emergent properties are in terms of reasoning, in terms of being able to solve complex multi-step problems."

These quotes highlight the innovation process, the impact of AI on developing practical solutions, the importance of iterative learning, and focusing on complex problem-solving capabilities in AI development.

title: Powering your Copilot for Data ‚Äì with Artem Keydunov of Cube.dev
author: Artyom Keydunov
intro: The first workshops and talks from the AI Engineer Summit are  now up ! Join the >20k viewers  on YouTube , find  clips on Twitter  (we‚Äôre also clipping  @latentspacepod ), and  chat with us on Discord ! Text-to-SQL was one of the first applications of NLP.  Thoughtspot  offered ‚ÄúAsk your data questions‚Äù as their core differentiation compared to traditional dashboarding tools. In a way, they provide a much friendlier interface with your own structured (aka ‚Äútabular‚Äù, as in ‚ÄúSQL tables‚Äù) data, the same way that RLHF and Instruction Tuning helped turn the GPT-3 of 2020 into the ChatGPT of 2022. Today, natural language queries on your databases are a commodity.  There are 4 different ChatGPT plugins that offer this, as well as a bunch of startups like one of our previous guests,  Seek.ai . Perplexity originally started with a similar product in 2022:   In  March 2023  LangChain wrote a blog post on LLMs and SQL highlighting  why they don‚Äôt consistently work : *  ‚ÄúLLMs can write SQL, but they are often prone to making up tables, making up field‚Äù *  ‚ÄúLLMs have some context window which limits the amount of text they can operate over‚Äù *  ‚ÄúThe SQL it writes may be incorrect for whatever reason, or it could be correct but just return an unexpected result.‚Äù For example, if you ask a model to ‚Äúreturn all active users in the last 7 days‚Äù it might hallucinate a `is_active` column, join to an `activity` table that doesn‚Äôt exist, or potentially get the wrong date (especially in leap years!). We previously talked to  Shreya Rajpal at Guardrails AI , which also supports Text2SQL enforcement. Their approach was to run the actual SQL against your database and then use the error messages to improve the query:   Semantic Layers to the rescue Cube  is an  open source  semantic layer which recently  integrated with LangChain  to solve these issues in a different way. You can use YAML, Javascript, or Python to create definitions of different metrics, measures and dimensions for your data:   Creating these metrics and passing them in the model context limits the possibility for errors as the model just needs to query the `active_users` view, and Cube will then expand that into the full SQL in a reliable way. The downside of this approach compared to the Guardrails one for example is that it requires more upfront work to define metrics, but on the other hand it leads to more reliable and predictable outputs.  The promise of adding a great semantic layer to your LLM app is irresistible - you greatly minimize hallucinations, make much more token efficient prompts, and your data stays up to date without any retraining or re-indexing. However, there are also difficulties with implementing semantic layers well, so we were glad to go deep on the topic with Artem as one of the leading players in this space!
timestamps: * [00:00:00] Introductions * [00:01:28] Statsbot and limitations of natural language processing in 2017 * [00:04:27] Building Cube as the infrastructure for Statsbot * [00:08:01] Open sourcing Cube in 2019 * [00:09:09] Explaining the concept of a semantic layer/Cube * [00:11:01] Using semantic layers to provide context for AI models working with tabular data * [00:14:47] Workflow of generating queries from natural language via semantic layer * [00:21:07] Using Cube to power customer-facing analytics and natural language interfaces * [00:22:38] Building data-driven AI applications and agents * [00:25:59] The future of the modern data stack * [00:29:43] Example use cases of Slack bots powered by Cube * [00:30:59] Using GPT models and limitations around math * [00:32:44] Tips for building data-driven AI apps * [00:35:20] Challenges around monetizing embedded analytics * [00:36:27] Lightning Round
ai_summary:
In this episode of the Latent Space podcast, hosts Swyx and Alessio engage in a comprehensive discussion with Artem Keydunov, co-founder of Cube, about the evolution of Cube from Statsbot, the challenges and advancements in data analytics, natural language processing, and the integration of AI in understanding and querying data. Artem reminisces about the inception of Statsbot, aiming to bring diverse data insights directly into Slack, tackling the challenges of natural language queries, and transitioning to developing Cube as a solution to create a semantic layer for easier data analysis. They explore the limitations of early machine learning models and the advancements leading to today's large language models (LLMs) that significantly improve natural language understanding and query generation. 

The conversation delves into the technicalities of building and using a semantic layer for data analysis, highlighting Cube's evolution into an open-source project and its significant role in the modern data stack. They touch upon the difficulties of monetizing embedded analytics and the impact of AI on automating and simplifying data workflows, from querying to transformation, emphasizing the potential for AI to augment human capabilities in data analysis rather than replace them.

Artem discusses the current trends in AI-driven analytics, such as the development of smarter chatbots and agents for internal data analysis and customer interaction, and the growing importance of a semantic layer in providing context to data for both humans and AI models. He envisions the future of data analytics where natural language interfaces become a standard feature in BI tools and analytics solutions, facilitated by the integration of AI models. Artem encourages the exploration of AI in analytics, emphasizing the rapid advancements in AI and its potential to revolutionize data understanding and decision-making processes.

Listeners are left with insights into the challenges and opportunities in leveraging AI for analytics, the importance of developing robust data infrastructure and semantic layers, and the potential for AI to transform the way businesses and individuals interact with and derive value from data.
key_insights:
1. Statsbot evolved from a Slack bot for analytics to Cube, focusing on semantic layers and open-source analytics infrastructure.
2. Early text-to-SQL attempts were limited by the lack of advanced large language models (LLMs) and natural language understanding.
3. The shift from Regex-based models to more complex natural language processing for text-to-SQL conversions.
4. The introduction of Cube as an open-source project to address the limitations faced by Statsbot, particularly in defining metrics and dimensions for data.
5. The evolution of language models has significantly improved the feasibility of building intelligent chatbots and analytics tools.
6. The concept of semantic layers as critical for translating natural language queries into actionable database queries.
7. The increasing role of AI and LLMs in the modern data stack, highlighting a shift towards natural language interfaces in analytics and business intelligence (BI).
8. The challenges of monetizing embedded analytics, despite its potential for creating user-facing data insights.
9. The importance of considering software engineering principles and practices in AI development, highlighting the unique aspects of AI compared to traditional software projects.
10. The potential of AI to augment data workflows, including data transformation and integration, by enabling more natural interfaces for non-technical users.
quotes:
1. **On Using Foundation Models and Contextual Indexing**:
   - "The first key step is to do some sort of indexing. That's what I was referring to, like write a book about your data, right? Describe in a text format what your data is about, right? Like what metrics it has, dimensions, what is the structures of that, what a relationship between those metrics, what are potential values of the dimensions." [00:12:26]

2. **On the Importance of a Semantic Layer**:
   - "Our take is that and my take is that semantic layer is just really good place for this context to leave because you need to give this context to the humans. You need to give that context to the AI system anyway, right? So that's why you define metric once and then, you know, like you teach your AI system what this metric is about." [00:11:01]

3. **On Building Resilient AI Applications**:
   - "I would just recommend going through to warehouse as soon as possible. I think a lot of people feel that MySQL can be a warehouse, which can be maybe on like a lower scale, but definitely not from a performance perspective. So just kind of starting with a good warehouse, a query engine, Lakehouse, that's probably like something I would recommend starting from a day zero." [00:31:32]

4. **On Collaboration in Semantic Layers**:
   - "I think the way I think about it is that at the end of the day, semantic layer is a code base. And in Cube, it's essentially a code base, right? It's not just a set of YAML files with pythons. I think code is never perfect, right? It's never going to be perfect. It will have a lot of, you know, like revisions of code. We have a version control, which helps it's easier with revisions. So I think we should treat our metrics and semantic layer as a code, right?" [00:16:53]

5. **On the Scope of AI in Data Engineering**:
   - "In terms of examples, I think a lot of people building different, you know, like agents or chatbots. You have a company that built an internal Slack bot that sort of answers questions, you know, like based on the data in a warehouse. And then like a lot of people kind of go in and like ask that chatbot this question. Is it like a real big use case? Maybe." [00:17:42]

These quotes highlight strategic perspectives on leveraging foundational models, the vital role of semantic layers, the importance of choosing the right data infrastructure, collaboration methods in modeling, and the current and potential applications of AI in data engineering.

title: The End of Finetuning ‚Äî with Jeremy Howard of Fast.ai
author: Alessio + swyx
intro: Thanks to the  over 17,000 people  who have joined the first AI Engineer Summit! A full recap is coming. Last call to fill out  the State of AI Engineering survey ! See our Community page for  upcoming meetups in SF, Paris and NYC . This episode had good interest  on Twitter  and was discussed on  the Vanishing Gradients podcast . Fast.ai‚Äôs  ‚ÄúPractical Deep Learning‚Äù courses  been watched by over >6,000,000 people, and the  fastai library  has over 25,000 stars on Github. Jeremy Howard, one of the creators of Fast, is now one of the most prominent and respected voices in the machine learning industry; but that wasn‚Äôt always the case.  Being non-consensus and right  In 2018, Jeremy and Sebastian Ruder published  a paper  on ULMFiT (Universal Language Model  Fine-tuning ), a 3-step transfer learning technique for NLP tasks:  The paper demonstrated that pre-trained language models could be fine-tuned on a specific task with a relatively small amount of data to achieve state-of-the-art results. They trained a 24M parameters model on WikiText-103 which was beat most benchmarks. While the paper had great results, the methods behind weren‚Äôt taken seriously by the community:  ‚ÄúEverybody hated fine tuning. Everybody hated transfer learning. I literally did tours trying to get people to start doing transfer learning and nobody was interested, particularly after GPT showed such good results with zero shot and few shot learning [‚Ä¶] which I was convinced was not the right direction, but who's going to listen to me, cause as you said, I don't have a PhD, not at a university‚Ä¶ I don't have a big set of computers to fine tune huge transformer models.‚Äù Five years later, fine-tuning is at the center of most major discussion topics in AI (we covered some like  fine tuning vs RAG  and  small models fine tuning ), and we might have gotten here earlier if Jeremy had OpenAI-level access to compute and distribution. At heart, Jeremy has always been  ‚ÄúGPU poor‚Äù : ‚ÄúI've always been somebody who does not want to build stuff on lots of big computers because most people don't have lots of big computers and I hate creating stuff that most people can't use.‚Äù This story is a good reminder of how some of the best ideas are hiding in plain sight; we recently covered  RWKV  and will continue to highlight the most interesting research that isn‚Äôt being done in the large labs.  Replacing fine-tuning with continued pre-training Even though fine-tuning is now mainstream, we still have a lot to learn. The issue of ‚Äú catastrophic forgetting ‚Äù and potential solutions have been brought up  in   many   papers : at the fine-tuning stage, the model can forget tasks it previously knew how to solve in favor of new ones.  The other issue is apparent memorization of the dataset even after a single epoch, which Jeremy covered  Can LLMs learn from a single example?  but we still don‚Äôt have the answer to.  Despite being the creator of ULMFiT, Jeremy still professes that there are a lot of open questions on finetuning: ‚ÄúSo I still don't know how to fine tune language models properly and I haven't found anybody who feels like they do.‚Äù He now advocates for  "continued pre-training"  - maintaining a diversity of data throughout the training process rather than separate pre-training and fine-tuning stages. Mixing instructional data, exercises, code, and other modalities while gradually curating higher quality data can avoid catastrophic forgetting and lead to more robust capabilities (something we covered in  Datasets 101 ). ‚ÄúEven though I originally created three-step approach that everybody now does, my view is it's actually wrong and we shouldn't use it‚Ä¶ the right way to do this is to fine-tune language models, is to actually  throw away the idea of fine-tuning . There's no such thing. There's only  continued pre-training.   And pre-training is something where from the very start, you try to include all the kinds of data that you care about, all the kinds of problems that you care about, instructions, exercises, code, general purpose document completion, whatever. And then as you train, you gradually curate that, you know, you gradually make that higher and higher quality and more and more specific to the kinds of tasks you want it to do. But  you never throw away any data ‚Ä¶. So yeah, that's now my view, is I think ULMFiT is the wrong approach. And that's why we're seeing a lot of these so-called alignment tax‚Ä¶  I think it's actually because people are training them wrong. An example of this phenomena is  CodeLlama , a LLaMA2 model finetuned on 500B tokens of code: while the model is much better at code, it‚Äôs worse on generic tasks that LLaMA2 knew how to solve well before the fine-tuning.  In the episode we also dive into all the places where open source model development and research is happening (academia vs Discords - tracked on  our Communities list  and on  our survey ), and how Jeremy recommends getting the most out of these diffuse, pseudonymous communities (similar to  the Eleuther AI Mafia ). Show Notes * Jeremy‚Äôs Background *  FastMail *  Optimal Decisions *  Kaggle *  Enlitic *  fast.ai *  Rachel Thomas *  Practical Deep Learning *  fastai for PyTorch *  nbdev *  fastec2  (the underrated library we describe) *  Can LLMs learn from a single example? * the  Kaggle LLM Science Exam  competition, which ‚Äúchallenges participants to answer difficult science-based questions written by a Large Language Model‚Äù. *  Sebastian Ruder *  Alec Radford *  Sylvain Gugger *  Stephen Merity *  Chris Lattner *  Modular.ai / Mojo *  Jono Whittaker *  Zeiler and Fergus paper *  ULM Fit *  DAWNBench *  Phi-1 *  Code Llama *  AlexNet
timestamps: * [00:00:00] Intros and Jeremy‚Äôs background * [00:05:28] Creating ULM Fit - a breakthrough in NLP using transfer learning * [00:06:32] The rise of GPT and the appeal of few-shot learning over fine-tuning * [00:10:00] Starting Fast.ai to distribute AI capabilities beyond elite academics * [00:14:30] How modern LMs like ChatGPT still follow the ULM Fit 3-step approach * [00:17:23] Meeting with Chris Lattner on Swift for TensorFlow at Google * [00:20:00] Continued pre-training as a fine-tuning alternative * [00:22:16] Fast.ai and looking for impact vs profit maximization * [00:26:39] Using Fast.ai to create an "army" of AI experts to improve their domains * [00:29:32] Fast.ai's 3 focus areas - research, software, and courses * [00:38:42] Fine-tuning memorization and training curve "clunks" before each epoch * [00:46:47] Poor training and fine-tuning practices may be causing alignment failures * [00:48:38] Academia vs Discords * [00:53:41] Jeremy's high hopes for Chris Lattner's Mojo and its potential * [01:05:00] Adding capabilities like SQL generation through quick fine-tuning * [01:10:12] Rethinking Fast.ai courses for the AI-assisted coding era * [01:14:53] Rapid model development has created major technical debt * [01:17:08] Lightning Round AI Summary (beta) This is the first episode we‚Äôre trying this. Here‚Äôs an overview of the main topics before you dive in the transcript.  * Jeremy's background and philosophies on AI * Studied philosophy and cognitive science in college * Focused on ethics and thinking about AI even 30 years ago * Believes AI should be accessible to more people, not just elite academics/programmers * Created fast.ai to make deep learning more accessible * Development of transfer learning and ULMFit * Idea of transfer learning critical for making deep learning accessible * ULMFit pioneered transfer learning for NLP * Proposed training general language models on large corpora then fine-tuning - this became standard practice * Faced skepticism that this approach would work from NLP community * Showed state-of-the-art results on text classification soon after trying it * Current open questions around fine-tuning LLMs * Models appear to memorize training data extremely quickly (after 1 epoch) * This may hurt training dynamics and cause catastrophic forgetting * Unclear how best to fine-tune models to incorporate new information/capabilities * Need more research on model training dynamics and ideal data mixing * Exciting new developments * Mojo and new programming languages like Swift could enable faster model innovation * Still lots of room for improvements in computer vision-like innovations in transformers * Small models with fine-tuning may be surprisingly capable for many real-world tasks * Prompting strategies enable models like GPT-3 to achieve new skills like playing chess at superhuman levels * LLMs are like computer vision in 2013 - on the cusp of huge new breakthroughs in capabilities * Access to AI research * Many key convos happen in private Discord channels and forums * Becoming part of these communities can provide great learning opportunities * Being willing to do real work, not just talk about ideas, is key to gaining access * The future of practical AI * Coding becoming more accessible to non-programmers through AI assistance * Pre-requisite programming experience for learning AI may no longer be needed * Huge open questions remain about how to best train, fine-tune, and prompt LLMs
ai_summary:
In the Latent Space Podcast episode, hosts Alessio and Swyx welcome Jeremy Howard, a significant figure in machine learning, all the way from Australia. They discuss a range of topics from Jeremy's unconventional academic journey at the University of Melbourne and his early work experiences at McKinsey, to his entrepreneurial ventures like founding both Optimal Decisions and FastMail in June 1989. Jeremy shares his journey of being at the forefront of using deep learning in medicine with Enlitic and later his venture into education and democratizing AI through Fast.ai, which he co-founded with Rachel Thomas. His work in promoting COVID-19 mask usage and his thoughts on using small businesses to mitigate failure risks were also highlighted.

Jeremy details his significant contribution to the field through the development of ULMFit, a precursor to multitask learning and Transformers, emphasizing the importance of transfer learning in making deep learning technology more accessible. He discusses the early skepticism around making deep learning accessible to non-experts and how Fast.ai aimed to change that narrative by providing practical skills in deep learning through their courses. Despite the success, Jeremy mentions the shifting focus towards models like GPT and the challenges he faced in advocating for transfer learning and fine-tuning models over zero-shot or few-shot learning approaches, which dominated the field for years.

Moreover, Jeremy touches upon his work with Kaggle and the surprise at the adoption of Fast.ai within major tech companies and AI research labs. His perspective on the importance of making deep learning technology accessible to a broader audience resonates through the conversation.

The discussion transitions into modular language model development, where Jeremy gives insights into the current state and future directions of AI research, mentioning his concerns about the lack of deep understanding of how language models learn and the need for more efficient and affordable AI solutions. He advocates for making coding and AI more accessible to all, reflecting on the potential for AI to democratize technology further and enable more people to contribute to its development positively.

Overall, the podcast episode presents a comprehensive view of Jeremy Howard's impactful work in AI and deep learning, emphasizing the importance of accessibility, education, and continuous exploration in the field.
key_insights:
1. AI Training Acceleration - There was a discussion about the development and acceleration of AI training capabilities. This aligns with broader trends in AI where training large models is becoming increasingly efficient and fast, though the specific insights or methods around acceleration weren't detailed in this conversation.
   
2. Modular AI Development - The conversation touched on modular, language-framework-level AI development, led by initiatives like Mojo, spearheaded by Chris Latner. These initiatives aim to make AI more accessible and customizable, potentially leading to more innovations and tailored AI solutions.
   
3. AI in Non-Physical Tasks - It was noted that AI capabilities in non-physical tasks have greatly expanded, underscoring AI's potential to outperform humans in various cognitive and analytical functions, which could have significant implications for many industries and professions.
   
4. Small Model Development - The importance of developing and fine-tuning smaller AI models was emphasized, suggesting this as a practical and accessible area for AI researchers to contribute, especially in scenarios where computational resources are limited.
   
5. Unexplored Training Dynamics in Language Models - The conversation highlighted the need for deeper understanding of how language models learn, including exploring training dynamics. This points toward a significant area of AI research that could lead to more efficient and effective model training processes.
   
6. Data Curation and Mixing for Model Training - There was a call for more rigorous analysis of what kinds of data are needed at what levels and at what times during model training. This includes understanding the mix of data needed to maintain or enhance a model's capabilities, which is crucial for optimizing AI training protocols.
   
7. Accessibility of AI Technologies - A strong message was given about the importance of making AI technologies accessible to a broader audience, beyond elite groups or individuals. This underscores a belief in the potential of widespread AI access to contribute positively to society.
   
8. Retrieval-Augmented Generation - The discussion touched on Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) as an area being explored for enhancing AI‚Äôs capabilities. However, RAG was also indicated as an inefficient hack suggesting a need for further improvement and innovation.
   
9. Use of Synthetic Data - Mention was made of the use of synthetic data in training AI models, which opens up possibilities for training on data that models might not encounter naturally. It points toward exploring new training methodologies that could significantly impact model efficacy.
   
10. AI‚Äôs Role in Chess Playing - The conversation included an interesting insight into AI's potential in playing chess, showcasing the ability of language models to potentially outperform traditional chess engines with the right prompting strategies. This serves as a unique example of AI's capabilities extending into areas previously dominated by specialized algorithms.
quotes:
. **[00:05:28]** "And we weren't sure if it was possible either, but we kind of felt like we had to give it a go because the alternative was we were pretty sure that deep learning was on its way to becoming, you know, the most or one of the most, you know, important technologies in human history. And if the only people that could use it were a handful of computer science PhDs, that seemed like A, a big waste and B, kind of dangerous."

2. **[00:18:17]** "you know, every way. Like the reason it took me so long to try it was because I asked all my friends in NLP if this could work. And everybody said, no, it definitely won't work."

3. **[00:22:16]** "I've always been somebody who does not want to build stuff on lots of big computers because most people don't have lots of big computers and I hate creating stuff that most people can't use."

4. **[00:28:56]** "I think it shows you don't necessarily need a huge amount of money and a huge team of people to make an impact."

5. **[00:39:01]** "And so we went back and like, okay, let's just run some experiments, you know, cause nobody seems to have actually published anything about this."

6. **[01:14:57]** "Google now does have a backup plan, you know, they have Jax, which was never a strategy. It was just a bunch of people who also recognized TensorFlow 2 as s**t and they just decided to build something else."

7. **[01:19:58]** "How do language models learn? You know, what are the training dynamics?"

title: Why AI Agents Don't Work (yet) - with Kanjun Qiu of Imbue
author: Kanjun Qiu
intro: Thanks to the  over 11,000 people  who joined us for the first AI Engineer Summit! A full recap is coming, but you can 1) catch up on the fun and videos on  Twitter  and  YouTube , 2) help us reach 1000 people for the first comprehensive  State of AI Engineering  survey and 3) submit projects for the new  AI Engineer Foundation . See our Community page for  upcoming meetups in SF, Paris, NYC, and Singapore .   This episode had good interest  on Twitter . Last month, Imbue was crowned as AI‚Äôs newest unicorn foundation model lab,  raising a $200m Series B at a >$1 billion valuation . As ‚Äústealth‚Äù foundation model companies go, Imbue (f.k.a. Generally Intelligent) has stood as an enigmatic group given they have no publicly released models to try out. However, ever since  their $20m Series A last year  their goal has been to ‚Äúdevelop generally capable AI agents with human-like intelligence in order to solve problems in the real world‚Äù. From RL to Reasoning LLMs Along with their Series A, they announced  Avalon ,  ‚ÄúA Benchmark for RL Generalization Using Procedurally Generated Worlds‚Äù.  Avalon is built on top of the open source Godot game engine, and is  ~100x faster  than Minecraft to enable fast RL benchmarking and a clear reward with adjustable game difficulty. After a while, they realized that pure RL isn‚Äôt a good path to teach reasoning and planning. The agents were able to learn mechanical things like opening complex doors, climbing, but  couldn‚Äôt go to higher level tasks . A pure RL world also doesn‚Äôt include a language explanation of the agent reasoning, which made it hard to understand why it made certain decisions. That pushed the team more towards the ‚Äú models for reasoning ‚Äù path: ‚ÄúThe second thing we learned is that  pure reinforcement learning is not a good vehicle for planning and reasoning . So these agents were able to learn all sorts of crazy things: They could learn to climb like hand over hand in VR climbing, they could learn to open doors like very complicated, like multiple switches and a lever open the door,  but they couldn't do any higher level things . And they couldn't do those lower level things consistently necessarily. And as a user,  I do not want to interact with a pure reinforcement learning end to end RL agent.  As a user, like I need much more control over what that agent is doing.‚Äù Inspired by  Chelsea Finn ‚Äôs work on  SayCan  at Stanford, the team pivoted to have their agents do the reasoning in natural language instead. This development parallels the large leaps in reasoning that humans have developed as the scientific method: ‚Äú We are better at reasoning now than we were 3000 years ago . An example of a reasoning strategy is noticing you're confused. Then when I notice I'm confused, I should ask: *  What was the original claim that was made?  *  What evidence is there for this claim?  *  Does the evidence support the claim?  *  Is the claim correct?  This is like a reasoning strategy that was developed in like the 1600s, you know, with like the advent of science. So that's an example of a reasoning strategy. There are tons of them. We employ all the time, lots of heuristics that help us be better at reasoning. And we can generate data that's much more specific to them.‚Äú The Full Stack Model Lab One year later, it would seem that the pivot to reasoning has had tremendous success, and Imbue has now reached a >$1B valuation, with participation from Astera Institute, NVIDIA, Cruise CEO Kyle Vogt, Notion co-founder Simon Last, and others. Imbue tackles their work with a ‚Äúfull stack‚Äù approach: *  Models.  Pretraining  very large (>100B parameter) models , optimized to perform well on internal reasoning benchmarks, with  a ~10,000 Nvidia H100 GPU cluster  lets us iterate rapidly on everything from training data to architecture and reasoning mechanisms. *  Tools and Agents.  Building internal productivity tools from  coding agents  for fixing type checking and linting errors, to sophisticated systems like  CARBS  (for  hyperparameter tuning and network architecture search). *  Interface Invention.  Solving agent trust and collaboration (not merely communication) with humans by creating better abstractions and interfaces ‚Äî IDEs for users to program computers in natural language. *  Theory.   Publishing research  about the theoretical underpinnings of self-supervised learning, as well as  scaling laws  for machine learning research. Kanjun believes we are still in the ‚Äúbare metal phase‚Äù of agent development, and they want to take a holistic approach to building the ‚Äúoperating system for agents‚Äù. We loved diving deep into the Imbue approach toward solving the AI Holy Grail of reliable agents, and are excited to share our conversation with you today!
timestamps: * [00:00:00] Introductions * [00:06:07] The origin story of Imbue * [00:09:39] Imbue's approach to training large foundation models optimized for reasoning * [00:12:18] Imbue's goals to build an "operating system" for reliable, inspectable AI agents * [00:15:37] Imbue's process of developing internal tools and interfaces to collaborate with AI agents * [00:17:27] Imbue's focus on improving reasoning capabilities in models, using code and other data * [00:19:50] The value of using both public benchmarks and internal metrics to evaluate progress * [00:21:43] Lessons learned from developing the Avalon research environment * [00:23:31] The limitations of pure reinforcement learning for general intelligence * [00:28:36] Imbue's vision for building better abstractions and interfaces for reliable agents * [00:31:36] Interface design for collaborating with, rather than just communicating with, AI agents * [00:37:40] The future potential of an agent-to-agent protocol * [00:39:29] Leveraging approaches like critiquing between models and chain of thought * [00:45:49] Kanjun's philosophy on enabling team members as creative agents at Imbue * [00:53:51] Kanjun's experience co-founding the communal co-living space The Archive * [01:00:22] Lightning Round Show Notes *  Imbue *  Avalon *  CARBS (hyperparameter optimizer) *  Series B announcement *  Kanjun/Imbue‚Äôs Podcast *  MIT Media Lab * Research mentioned: *  Momentum Contrast *  SimClr *  Chelsea Finn  -  SayCan *  Agent Protocol  - part of the  AI Engineer Foundation *  Xerox PARC *  Michael Nielsen *  Jason Benn *  Outset Capital *  Scenius - Kevin Kelly *  South Park Commons *  The Archive *  Thursday Nights in AI
ai_summary:
In the Latent Space Podcast, co-hosts Alessio and Swyx welcome Kanjun Qiu from Imbue (formerly Generally Intelligent). Kanjun, who has a rich background from MIT to Dropbox and as a thrice founder, discusses the rebranding from Generally Intelligent to Imbue, focusing on Imbue's journey into enhancing AI's capacity for human agency and potential. She shares her personal drive outside of work, emphasizing her passion for human agency and the development of systems that boost effectiveness and creativity. Kanjun recounts her path from founding Ember and Sorceress to realizing the potential of AI in augmenting human capabilities and her current work at Imbue towards developing trusted AI agents and interfaces.

Kanjun explores the challenges in creating AI that genuinely augments human abilities, stating that reasoning and trustworthiness are central to deploying effective AI agents in the real world. Imbue's approach involves training large foundation models optimized for reasoning, building robust internal tools for research and development, and fostering a unique company culture centered on unlocking individual superpowers.

The discussion also touches on Kanjun's perspective on the future of personal computing, rekindled through AI agents capable of offloading and enhancing our intellectual tasks. She mentions the importance of developing non-leaky abstractions and user-friendly interfaces for higher reliability and trust in AI systems. Towards the end, Kanjun articulates her vision for AI's role in addressing the world's challenges by providing "free intellectual energy" and the necessity of thoughtful regulation and safety measures to ensure AI's positive impact.
key_insights:
1. Imbue, previously Generally Intelligent, focuses on creating AI agents and interfaces that are trustworthy and can perform long-range goals through understanding and employing human reasoning.
2. Sorceress, an AI product developed by Imbue's founders, automated recruitment by finding suitable candidates and facilitating outreach, revealing early insights into creating AI systems that users can trust and rely on.
3. AI research is trending towards self-supervised learning, reflecting a direction where AI models learn in a way akin to human learning, without needing explicit supervision.
4. Imbue aims to rekindle the dream of the personal computer by developing large foundation models optimized for reasoning to create more capable and trustworthy agents.
5. The importance of building non-leaky abstractions in AI agents to ensure reliability and deployability, drawing parallels to software development's evolution towards higher level programming languages.
6. Utilizing code as a form of explicit reasoning data significantly benefits AI model training by providing clear, structured examples of logical processes.
7. The challenge of long-term memory and context in AI models, highlighting the necessity of developing systems that can store and utilize vast amounts of information for complex tasks.
8. The initiative to co-build evaluations for AI agents with other developers, addressing the need for benchmarks that accurately measure an agent's effectiveness in various applications.
9. Imbue's approach of dogfooding, or using its own AI agents internally, as a core strategy for developing practical and effective solutions.
10. The exploration of AI policy and regulation, with Imbue actively participating in analyzing and proposing guidelines to ensure that AI technologies are deployed in ways that are beneficial and not harmful.
quotes:
1. "I just really believe that as humans, we can be a lot more than we are. And it's what drives everything." (Kanjun at [00:02:03])

2. "What Josh and I were really interested in is how can we get computers that help us do bigger things?" (Kanjun at [00:06:07])

3. "A lot of what we do at Imbue is working on interfaces to figure out how do we get to a situation where when you're building and using agents, these agents are trustworthy to the end user." (Kanjun at [00:05:52])

4. "Code is the most explicit example of reasoning data on the internet." (Kanjun at [00:32:08])

5. "We're in a historic moment where we'll look back and be like, 'Oh my God, the future was invented in these years.'" (Kanjun at [01:01:09])

6. "AI is a tool like any technology... the world could be much better, could be much more thoughtful because of that." (Kanjun at [01:01:53])

7. "The takeaway is like the future could be really exciting if we can actually get agents that are able to do these bigger things. Reasoning is the biggest blocker plus these sets of abstractions to make things more robust and reliable." (Kanjun at [01:04:36])

These quotes encapsulate themes of human potential and agency, the transformative power of AI, the importance of creating trustworthy AI agents, the unique contributions of coding to AI reasoning, the significant moment we're in for AI development, the optimistic view of how AI can improve the world, and the challenges and potential of AI agents in the future.

title: [AIE Summit Preview #1] Swyx on Software 3.0 and the Rise of the AI Engineer
author: Alessio + swyx
intro: This is a special double weekend crosspost of AI podcasts, helping attendees prepare for the  AI Engineer Summit  next week. Swyx gave a keynote on the Software 3.0 Landscape recently (referenced in  our recent Humanloop episode ) and was invited to go deeper in podcast format, and to preview the  AI Engineer Summit Schedule .  For those seeking to ramp up on the current state of thinking on AI Engineering, this should be the perfect place to start, alongside our upcoming  Latent Space University course  (which is being tested live for the first time at the Summit workshops). While you are listening, there are two things you can do to be part of the AI Engineer experience. One,  join the AI Engineer Summit Slack . Two,  take the State of AI Engineering survey  and help us get to 1000 respondents!  Full transcript available  here !  Links *  AI Engineer Summit  (Join livestream and Slack community) *  State of AI Engineering Survey  (please help us fill this out to represent you!) *  Podrocket full episode  by  Tejas Kumar Show notes *  Explaining Software 1.0, 2.0, and 3.0 * Software 1.0: Hand-coded software with conditional logic, loops, etc. * Software 2.0: Machine learning models like neural nets trained on data * Software 3.0: Using large pre-trained foundation models without needing to collect/label training data *  Foundation Models and Model Architecture * Foundation models like GPT-3/4, Claude, Whisper - can be used off the shelf via API * Model architecture refers to the layers and structure of a ML model * Grabbing a pre-trained model lets you skip data collection and training *  Putting Foundation Models into Production * Levels of difficulty: calling an API, running locally, fully serving high-volume predictions * Key factors: GPU utilization, batching, infrastructure expertise *  The Emerging AI Developer Landscape * AI is becoming more accessible to "traditional" software engineers * Distinction between ML engineers and new role of AI engineers * AI engineers consume foundation model APIs vs. developing models from scratch *  The Economics of AI Engineers * Demand for AI exceeds supply of ML experts to build it * AI engineers will emerge out of software engineers learning these skills *  Defining the AI Engineering Stack * System of reasoning: Foundation model APIs * Retrieval augmented generation (RAG) stack: Connects models to data * AI UX: New modalities and interfaces beyond chatbots *  Building Products with Foundation Models * Replicating existing features isn't enough - need unique value * Focus on solving customer problems and building trust *  AI Skepticism and Hype * Some skepticism is healthy, but "AI blame" also emerges * High expectations from media/industry creators * Important to stay grounded in real customer needs *  Meaningful AI Applications * Many examples of AI positively impacting lives already * Engineers have power to build and explore - lots of opportunity *  Closing and AI Engineer Summit Details * October 8-10 virtual conference for AI engineers * Speakers from OpenAI, Microsoft, Amazon, etc * Free to attend online   Get full access to Latent Space at  www.latent.space/subscrib

title: RAG Is A Hack - with Jerry Liu from LlamaIndex
author: Jerry Liu
intro: Want to help define  the AI Engineer stack ? >800 folks have weighed in on the top tools, communities and builders for the first  State of AI Engineering  survey, which we will present for the first time at next week‚Äôs  AI Engineer Summit . Join us  online ! This post had robust discussion on  HN  and  Twitter . In October 2022, Robust Intelligence hosted an internal hackathon to play around with LLMs which led to the creation of two of the most important AI Engineering tools: LangChain ü¶ú‚õìÔ∏è ( our interview with Harrison here ) and LlamaIndex ü¶ô by Jerry Liu, which we‚Äôll cover today. In less than a year, LlamaIndex has crossed 600,000 monthly downloads, raised $8.5M from Greylock, has a fast growing open source community that contributes to LlamaHub, and it doesn‚Äôt seem to be slowing down. LlamaIndex‚Äôs Origin (aka GPT Tree Index) Jerry struggled to make large amounts of data work with GPT-3 (which had a 4,096 tokens context window). Today LlamaIndex is at the forefront of the RAG wave (Retrieval Augmented Generation), but in the beginning Jerry wasn‚Äôt focused on embeddings and search, but rather on understanding how models could summarize, link, and reason about data.  On November 5th, Jerry pushed the  first version  to Github under the name ‚ÄúGPT Tree Index‚Äù:  The GPT Tree Index first takes in a large dataset of unprocessed text data as input. It then builds up a tree-index in a bottom-up fashion; each parent node is able to summarize the children nodes using a general  summarization prompt ; each intermediate node containing summary text summarizing the components below. Once the index is built, it can be saved to disk and loaded for future use. Then, say the user wants to use GPT-3 to answer a question. Using a  query prompt template , GPT-3 will be able to recursively perform tree traversal in a top-down fashion in order to answer a question. For example, in the very beginning GPT-3 is tasked with selecting between *n* top-level nodes which best answers a provided query, by outputting a number as a multiple-choice problem. The GPT Tree Index then uses the number to select the corresponding node, and the process repeats recursively among the children nodes until a leaf node is reached. [‚Ä¶] How is this better than an embeddings-based approach / other state-of-the-art QA and retrieval methods? The intent is not to compete against existing methods. A simpler embedding-based technique could be to just encode each chunk as an embedding and do a simple question-document embedding look-up to retrieve the result. This project is a simple exercise to test how GPT can organize and lookup information. The project attracted a lot of attention early on (the announcement tweet has ~330 likes), but it wasn‚Äôt until ~February 2023 that the open source community really started to explode, which was around the same time that LlamaHub was released. LlamaHub made it easy for developers to import data from Google Drive, Discord, Slack, databases, and more into their LlamaIndex projects.   What is LlamaIndex?  As we mentioned, LlamaIndex is leading the charge in the development of the RAG stack. RAG boils down to two parts: *  Indexing  (i.e. how do you load and index the data in your knowledge base) *  Querying  (i.e. how do you surface the data and fit it in the model context)  Indexing To get your data from all your sources to your RAG knowledge base, you can leverage a few tools:  *  Documents / Nodes : A Document is a generic container around any data source - for instance, a PDF, an API output, or retrieved data from a database. A Node is the atomic unit of data in LlamaIndex and represents a ‚Äúchunk‚Äù of a source Document (i.e. one Document has many Node) as well as its relationship to other Node objects. *  Data Connectors : A data connector ingest data from different sources and turn them into Document representations (text and simple metadata). These connectors are offered through  LlamaHub , and there are over 200 of them today. *  Data Indexes : Once you‚Äôve ingested your data, LlamaIndex will help you index the data into a format that‚Äôs easy to retrieve. There are many  types of indexes  (Summary, Tree, Vector, etc). Under the hood, LlamaIndex parses the raw documents into intermediate representations, calculates vector embeddings, and infers metadata. The most commonly used index is the  VectorStoreIndex , which can then be paired with any of the vector stores out there ( an example with Chroma ). Querying The RAG pipeline, during the querying phase, sources the most pertinent context from a user's prompt, forwarding it along to the LLM. This equips the LLM with current / private knowledge beyond its foundational training data. LlamaIndex offers adaptable modules tailored for building RAG pathways for Q&A, chatbots, or agent use, since each of them has different requirements. For example, a chatbot should expect the user to interject with follow up questions, while an agent will try to carry out a whole task on its own without user intervention.   Building Blocks *  Retrievers : A retriever defines how to efficiently retrieve relevant context from a knowledge base (i.e. index) when given a query. Vector index is the most popular mode, but there are  other options  like Summary, Tree, Keyword Table, Knowledge Graph, and Document Summary.   *  Node Postprocessors : Once the retriever gets you Node objects back, you will need to do additional work like discarding low similarity ones. There are  many options  here as well, such as `SimilarityPostprocessor` (i.e. drop nodes below a certain similarity score) or `LongContextReorder` which helps avoid the issues raised in the ‚Äú Lost in the Middle, U-shaped recollection curve ‚Äù paper.  *  Response Synthesizers : Takes a user query and your retrieved chunks, and prompts and LLM with them. There are a few  response modes  here that balance thoroughness and compactness. Pipelines *  Query Engines : A query engine is an end-to-end pipeline that allow you to ask question over your data. It takes in a natural language query, and returns a response, along with reference context retrieved and passed to the LLM. This makes it possible to do things like  ‚ÄúAsk panda questions‚Äù  by leveraging Panda dataframes as a data source.  *  Chat Engines : A chat engine is an end-to-end pipeline for having a conversation with your data (multiple back-and-forth instead of a single question & answer). This supports traditional OpenAI-style chat interfaces, as well as more advanced ones like  ReAct . *  Agents : An agent is an automated decision maker (powered by an LLM) that interacts with the world via a set of tools. Agent may be used in the same fashion as query engines or chat engines, but they have the power to both read and write data. For reasoning, you can use either OpenAI Functions or ReAct. Both can leverage the tools offered through LlamaHub for further analysis. RAG vs Finetuning Now that you have a full overview of what LlamaIndex does, the next question is ‚ÄúWhen should I use this and when should I fine tune?‚Äù. Jerry‚Äôs TLDR is that ‚ÄúRAG is just a hack‚Äù, but a powerful one. Each option has pros and cons: *  Lower investment:  RAG requires almost 0 upfront investment, unlike finetuning which requires data cleaning, model training, increased costs for finetuned inference, etc. *  Stricter access control and higher visibility:  when finetuning, the model learns everything. With RAG, you can decide what documents the index should have access to, making it more secure by default. You are also able to see everything that was passed into the context if a response doesn‚Äôt look right. *  Context window limitation:  you can only fit so many tokens into the prompt due to the way models work. Finetuning helps you circumvent that by compressing the knowledge into the model weights rather than putting it in the prompt.    As Jerry says, the best way to know this inside out is  to learn to build RAG from scratch  (without LlamaIndex) - and they have plenty of tutorials on his Twitter and blog to learn this. The other issue is that the math for finetuning isn‚Äôt well known yet as we  discussed with Quentin Anthony from Eleuther , so unless you have money and time to invest into exploring fine tuning, you‚Äôre better off starting with RAG.   Full YouTube Discussion! Show Notes *  LlamaIndex *  LlamaHub *  SEC Insights *  Robust Intelligence *  Quora‚Äôs Poe *  Chroma *  Vespa *  Why should every AI engineer learn to build RAG from scratch ? *  LangChain *  Gorilla *  Lost in the Middle: How Language Models Use Long Contexts

ai_summary:
In the "Latent Space Podcast," hosts Alessio and Swyx interview Jerry Liu, a prominent figure in the AI and machine learning community. Throughout the conversation, they delve into Jerry's academic background, which includes a bachelor's in computer science and a certificate in finance from Princeton. They touch on Jerry's professional journey, highlighting his roles as a machine learning engineer at Quora and Uber, as well as his contributions to AI research and development at various companies.

A significant portion of the discussion revolves around Jerry's efforts in making deep learning advancements more accessible through platforms like Quora and his work on generative adversarial networks (GANs), among other topics. They also explore the foundation and objectives of LlamaIndex, Jerry's recent venture that aims to enhance LLM (Large Language Model) applications by addressing challenges related to data accessibility, retrieval, and synthesis. Jerry shares insights on how his experience in AI research and machine learning engineering has informed the development of LlamaIndex, emphasizing the startup's focus on optimizing the interaction between large language models and extensive data sets.

Additionally, they discuss ongoing trends in the AI industry, including the growing importance of fine-tuning and retrieval techniques in LLMs, the potential impacts of evolving model architectures, and the significance of open-source contributions to fostering innovation in the field. The conversation also highlights the collaborative nature of AI development, referencing Jerry's interactions with other experts and companies striving to push the boundaries of what's possible with AI technologies.

Towards the end of the podcast, the discussion shifts to future directions for LlamaIndex and the broader AI landscape. Jerry expresses optimism about the advancements in personalized AI applications and theorizes about the potential convergence of structured and unstructured data querying to enhance the power and precision of AI-driven insights.

Overall, the podcast provides an in-depth look into Jerry Liu's contributions and perspectives on the evolving world of AI and machine learning, offering listeners valuable insights into the challenges, opportunities, and future prospects of the field.
key_insights:
1. The increasing accessibility of generative AI is fundamentally changing how AI research and applications are developed, making it more accessible to a broader range of developers and researchers.
2. The concept of Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) as a hack, but a very effective and crucial one for current AI applications, signaling a potential shift towards more end-to-end optimized models in the future.
3. The idea that fine-tuning and RAG will evolve to include more sophisticated data retrieval beyond embeddings, potentially integrating more complex reasoning and structured data querying.
4. The potential of OpenSource models and platforms to challenge the dominance of proprietary models by OpenAI and other companies, driven by market demand for more open and versatile solutions.
5. The importance of synthetic dataset generation for evaluation, providing a scalable solution for evaluating models more efficiently than traditional human annotation.
6. The emergent need for better tools and practices around RAG development, including understanding how to effectively chunk, parse data, and optimize retrieval mechanisms.
7. The role of personalization and memory in AI, indicating an unexplored territory in AI research that could lead to more personalized AI applications through continuous fine-tuning and innovative model architectures.
8. The potential for new retrieval techniques that blend old information retrieval principles with new LLM capabilities, like chain of thought reasoning and graph-based data representations, for more sophisticated data interactions.
quotes:
**[00:40:16] Jerry:** "I think the thing is when people start out, like they will probably use these loaders and it's a great tool to get started. But if you get to a point where you actually want to call like an API that hasn't been supported yet, or, you know, you want to load in stuff in metadata or something that hasn't been directly baked into the logic of a loader itself, people start adding up, like writing their own custom loaders. And that is a thing that we're seeing."

**[00:42:55] Jerry:** "I mean, I think for us, it's more, we just have a very flexible like document abstraction that you can fill in with any content that you want."

**[00:48:53] Jerry:** "One is just like kind of more detailed guides on like different modular components within it. So if you're like a full stack developer, you can go in and actually take the pieces that you want and actually kind of build your own custom flows."

**[00:55:49] Jerry:** "I think part of what I wanted to talk about a conceptual level, especially with the idea of like thinking about what is the minimum context? [...] The way I kind of think about this from a more principled manner is like you have like, there's this concept of like information capacity, just this idea of like entropy, like given any fixed amount of like storage space, like how much information can you actually compact in there?"

**[01:04:23] Jerry:** "I think just the ability of LLMs to generate believable outputs and for text and also for images. And I think just the whole reason I started hacking around with LLMs, honestly, I felt like I got into it pretty late. I should've gotten into it like early 2022 because UB23 had been out for a while. Like just the fact that there was this engine that was capable of like reasoning and no one was really like tapping into it."

**[01:06:24] Jerry:** "I'd probably work on some aspect of, um, like personalization of memory. Like, I think I actually think that I don't think anyone's like, I think a lot of people have thoughts about that, but like, for what it's worth, I don't think the final state will be right. I think it will be some, some like fancy algorithm or architecture where you like bake it into like the architecture of the model itself."

---

These quotes shine a light on the shifting landscape of AI, embedding system design, and the fascinating future possibilities in AI, especially around the personalization of memory and the capabilities of LLMs beyond current utilizations.

intro: Want to help define the AI Engineer stack? Have opinions on the top tools, communities and builders? We‚Äôre collaborating with friends at Amplify to launch  the first State of AI Engineering survey ! Please  fill it out  (and tell your friends)! In March, we started off our GPT4 coverage framing one of this year‚Äôs key forks in the road as the ‚Äú Year of Multimodal vs Multimodel AI ‚Äù. 6 months in, neither has panned out yet. The vast majority of LLM usage still defaults to chatbots built atop OpenAI ( per our LangSmith discussion ), and  rumored GPU shortages  have prevented the broader rollout of GPT-4 Vision. Most "AI media‚Äù demos like  AI Drake  and  AI South Park  turned out heavily human engineered, to the point where the AI label is more marketing than honest reflection of value contributed. However, the biggest impact of multimodal AI in our lives this year has been a relatively simple product - the  daily HN Recap podcast  produced by Wondercraft.ai, a 5 month old AI podcasting startup. As swyx  observed , the ‚Äú content flippening ‚Äù ‚Äî an event horizon when  the majority of content you choose to consume is primarily AI generated/augmented  rather than primarily human/manually produced ‚Äî has now gone from  unthinkable  to  possible .
