title: Doing it the Hard Way: Making the AI engine and language üî• of the future ‚Äî with Chris Lattner of Modular
author: Alessio + swyx
intro: Want to help define the AI Engineer stack? Have opinions on the top tools, communities and builders? We‚Äôre collaborating with friends at Amplify to launch the first  State of AI Engineering  survey! Please  fill it out  (and tell your friends)! If AI is so important, why is its software so bad? This was the motivating question for  Chris Lattner  as he reconnected with his product counterpart on Tensorflow,  Tim Davis , and started working on  a modular solution  to the problem of sprawling, monolithic, fragmented platforms in AI development. They  announced a $30m seed  in 2022 and, following their  successful double launch  of Modular/Mojoüî• in May, have just announced  their $100m Series A . While the performance claims of Mojoüî• and its promise as a fully multithreaded compiled Python superset stole the show, we were amazed to learn that it is a side project - and the vision for Modular‚Äôs Python inference engine is at least as big. Listeners will recall that we last talked with  George Hotz  about his work on tinygrad and how he wants to replace PyTorch with something faster and lighter, handwriting a ‚Äúreduced instruction set‚Äù of operators himself. But what if the problem could be solved at even lower level - with the Python engine/runtime itself? Chris on Compilers Chris‚Äô history with compilers is well known - creating LLVM during his PhD (for which he won the 2012  ACM Software System Award ), hired straight into Apple where he also made Clang and Swift (the iPhone programming language that replaced Objective-C), then leading the Tensorflow Infrastructure team at Google where he built  XLA , a just-in-time compiler for optimizing a lot of the algebra behind TF‚Äôs workloads, and  MLIR , a modular compiler framework that sat above LLVM to optimize ML graphs and kernels that were hard to represent in the LLVM IR.   So as pretty much the best compiler engineer in human history, you‚Äôd justifiably assume that Chris is simply choosing to take his compiler approach to Python. And yet  that is not how he thinks about compilers at all .  As he says in our chat, ‚ÄúHow do you enable invention?  How do you get more kinds of people that understand different parts of this problem to actually collaborate? And so this is where I see our work on Mojo and on the engine‚Ä¶ ‚Ä¶ I don't have a compiler hammer that I'm running around looking for compiler problems to hit.‚Äù Today a small number of people at companies like OpenAI spend a lot of time manually writing CUDA kernels. But an optimizing compiler for AI leads to  compilers as a means to an end for increasing software collaboration , expanding the ability of people with different skillsets and knowledge. ‚Äú‚Ä¶What is the fundamental purpose of a compiler? Well, it's to make it so that you don't have to know as much about the hardware. You could write everything in very low-level assembly code for every single problem that you have‚Ä¶ But what a compiler really does is it allows you to  express things at a higher level of abstraction .‚Äù For Chris, compilers are also ways to  properly automate generalized optimizations  that might otherwise be manually coded and brittle abstractions, like operator fusion: ‚ÄúSo NVIDIA goes and they build this really cool library called FasterTransformer. The performance point of using it is massive. So a lot of LLM companies and other folks use this thing because they want the performance. ‚Ä¶Here's the problem.  If you want to go innovate in transformers, now you're constrained by what FasterTransformer can do , right?  And so, again, you come back to where are compilers useful? They're useful for generalization. If you can get the same quality result or better than FasterTransformer, but with a generalized architecture, well now you can get the best of both worlds, where you have orthogonality and composability, you enable research, you also get better performance.‚Äù Done correctly, these operator optimizations being implemented at the compiler level amount to an ‚ÄúAI Engine‚Äù that can not only survive, but  enable  major architecture shifts should a  credible alternative LLM architecture  come along someday. Modular ‚Äî the Unified AI Engine Modular‚Äôs original goal was to build the ‚ÄúUnified AI Engine‚Äù to speed up AI development and inference - one that doesn‚Äôt assume an ‚ÄúAI = GPUs‚Äù world that only benefits the ‚ÄúGPU-rich‚Äù, but one that  treats AI as ‚Äúa large-scale, heterogeneous, parallel compute problem‚Äù . Modular itself is an engine (separate from Mojo, which we cover below) that can run all other frameworks between 10% to 650% faster on CPUs (with GPU support coming in the fall): At Google, Chris‚Äô job wasn‚Äôt to build the best possible compiler for AI. The goal was to build the best compiler  for TPUs , so that all TensorFlow users would have a great Google Cloud experience. Similarly, the PyTorch team at Meta isn‚Äôt trying to make AI faster for the world, but mostly for their recommendations and ads systems. Chris and Tim realized that the AI engine and developer experience isn‚Äôt a product prioritized by any of the big tech companies (they tried) - so they see Modular as the best way to deliver the AI development platform of the future.  The modularity of Modular shines through in  the hot-swapping Inference Engine demo , which has to be seen to be believed. Mojo üî• ‚Äî Blazing Fast Python The other piece of Modular is  Mojo , a new programming language for AI that is a superset of Python. In some sense it is  ‚Äúthe ultimate yak shave‚Äù : We were shocked to learn that Chris and the team didn‚Äôt initially set out to create Mojo, but it started life as an internal DSL to make themselves more productive. Mojo adopted Python‚Äôs syntax since it‚Äôs by far the most used language in machine learning and AI. It also lets them supports all existing PyPi packages, requiring no code changes for developers to go from Python to Mojo. Mojo comes with a lot of different underlying design choices that lead to much better performance: * It‚Äôs compiled rather than interpreted like Python * No  GIL  which allows for multi-threading * Better heap representation * Leverages MLIR In the perfect test scenario that leverages all of these improvements, Mojo is up to  ~68,000x faster  than Python üî• (fire emoji is a valid file extension for Mojo files, btw!).  Of course, that is just one microbenchmark, but as  Jeremy Howard explains , most Python codebases should run between 10-100x faster simply by moving to Mojo with very minor adjustments.  A  community member port of Llama2 from Python to Mojo  shows it inferencing >100x faster than Python, and 20% faster than the handcoded raw C implementation. The Modular team is embarking in one of the hardest technical challenges we‚Äôve seen a startup tackle, and we can‚Äôt wait to see what comes out of it. We had an amazing conversation with Chris diving into all the details, which we hope you enjoy! Show Notes *  Modular AI *  Chris‚Äô personal website *  Scott Forstall *  Bret Victor‚Äôs Playgrounds * Karpathy‚Äôs Tweets *  Speculative Execution *  Llama memory constraints *  LLVM *  Clang *  Swift *  TensorFlow *  PyTorch *  XLA *  MLIR *  TPUs *  Guido van Rossum
timestamps: * [00:00:00] Introduction * [00:00:40] Chris's background - LLVM, Clang, Swift * [00:03:01] Chris's experience with Google TPUs and XLA * [00:05:47] The limitations of current frameworks like TensorFlow and PyTorch * [00:08:03] The benefits of using compilers for AI systems * [00:13:14] Enabling more collaboration between researchers through better systems * [00:20:55] Starting with CPU optimization instead of just GPUs * [00:24:36] Design principles and goals behind Modular * [00:32:41] The benefits of starting from a general compiler architecture * [00:35:13] Origins of deciding to create the Mojo language * [00:44:43] Goals for Mojo to become a true Python superset * [00:48:12] Thoughts on tinygrad * [00:52:00] ggml, quantization, etc * [00:57:00] Speculative execution and other gains from making Mojo more parallel * [01:01:50] Future of Mojo‚Äôs toolkit * [01:07:00] Why Modular is a company and not a foundation * [01:11:00] Learnings as a first time founder and engineering leader * [01:25:00] Lightning Round
ai_summary: In this episode of the Latent Space Podcast, hosts Alessio and Swyx engage in a fascinating conversation with Chris Lattner, a prominent figure in the fields of software development and AI infrastructure. Chris shares insights from his extensive career, including his early involvement with Apple, where he developed LLVM and later Swift, and his experiences at Tesla, Google, and SiFive. The discussion delves into the challenges and innovations in AI development, highlighting Chris's work on the Modular AI engine and Mojo, a Python superset aimed at unifying and simplifying AI development across various hardware platforms. They explore the implications of compiler technology in AI, the importance of ASIC-friendly designs, and the future directions of AI frameworks. Chris emphasizes the necessity of reducing complexity in AI infrastructure to enable broader innovation and collaboration within the field.
key_insights:
1. AI infrastructure is evolving towards addressing both software and hardware integration issues to enhance efficiency and flexibility in AI applications.
2. Modular, the unified AI engine developed by Chris Lattner's team, aims to solve the fragmentation and complexity in current AI research and development by treating AI as a large-scale, heterogeneous, parallel compute problem.
3. Chris highlights the significance of compilers in AI research, suggesting that they can be more scalable and adaptable than manually written kernels, touching on the benefits of compiler techniques like kernel fusion for reducing memory traffic and enabling new model architectures.
4. Modular's approach includes Mojo, a Python superset, that allows for greater expressiveness and efficiency, particularly for systems programming in AI, with the ultimate goal of simplifying AI model deployment across various hardware platforms.
5. Chris discusses the collaboration and community aspect in AI development, emphasizing the importance of an ecosystem where different experts like researchers, system engineers, and hardware specialists can work together to push forward AI advancements.
6. The AI infrastructure challenge is presented as not solely a technical issue but also a matter of correctly aligning incentives, strategy, and user-centric product development in the fast-evolving AI landscape.
quotes:
Given the comprehensive insights shared by Chris Lattner, the following quotes encapsulate actionable advice and perspectives that could significantly influence AI engineers' thinking and behavior:

1. **On the importance of compiler technology in AI (00:08:03):** "And so one of the things I love about the NVIDIA platform in particular is that if you look at CUDA, like many people get grumpy about CUDA for various reasons, but you go all the way back to when AI took off, like deep learning took off with the AlexNet moment, for example, right? So many people will credit the AlexNet moment as being a combination of two things. They say it's data, ImageNet, and compute, the power of the GPUs coming together. And that's what allowed the AlexNet moment to happen. But the thing they often forget is that the third part was programmability because CUDA enabled researchers to go invent convolution kernels that did not exist, right? There was no TensorFlow back then. There was none of the stuff that existed. And so it's actually this triumvirate between data compute and programmability that enabled a novel kind of research to kick off this invention that became the entire wave of deep learning systems, right?"

2. **On simplifying AI technology stacks (00:13:14):** "That's a lot of what we're going to talk about today with Modular Mojo. Well, so that's the brief history and you started Modular in 2022, about 20 months ago. What's one other thing on the personal side that people should know about you that people don't see on the LinkedIn because you're all into hardware-software boundaries and stuff?"

3. **On enabling research through improved AI infrastructure (00:17:08):** "So I believe in properly modular, properly layered, properly designed technology. And so if you get the abstractions right, you can do really cool things like this."

4. **On the evolution of AI frameworks (01:21:09):** "Another third is the frameworks. So you've got TensorFlow, you got PyTorch, you got TVM, you got like all this stuff out there. All these things were, you know, they're eight years old. The infrastructure itself was research, right? These things were built in a different era of what ML was, and they got evolved along the way and new hardware and new use cases and all this stuff. And they were never intentionally designed by, you know, from what we know now."

These quotes underscore the imperative of harnessing compiler advancements for AI development, taking first-principles approaches to tackle AI's architectural challenges, the invaluable role of programmability in fostering AI breakthroughs, and the urgency of rethinking and evolving AI frameworks to align with contemporary AI challenges and opportunities.

title: The Point of LangChain ‚Äî with Harrison Chase of LangChain
author: Harrison Chase
intro: As alluded to on the pod, LangChain has  just launched LangChain Hub : ‚Äúthe go-to place for developers to discover new use cases and polished prompts.‚Äù It‚Äôs available to everyone with a LangSmith account, no invite code necessary.  Check it out ! In 2023, LangChain has speedrun the race from 2:00 to 4:00 to 7:00  Silicon Valley Time . From the back to back  $10m Benchmark seed  and (rumored)  $20-25m Sequoia Series A  in April, to back to back critiques of ‚Äú LangChain is Pointless ‚Äù and ‚Äú The Problem with LangChain ‚Äù in July, to  teaching with Andrew Ng  and keynoting at basically every AI conference this fall (including  ours ), it has been an  extreme  rollercoaster for Harrison and his  growing  team creating one of the most popular (>60k stars at time of writing) building blocks for AI Engineers. LangChain‚Äôs Origins The  first commit to LangChain  shows its humble origins as a light wrapper around Python‚Äôs formatter.format for  prompt templating . But as Harrison tells the story, even his first experience with text-davinci-002 in early 2022 was focused on chatting with data from their internal company Notion and Slack, what is now known as  Retrieval Augmented Generation (RAG) .  As the Generative AI meetup scene came to life post Stable Diffusion, Harrison saw a need for common abstractions for what people were building with text LLMs at the time: *  LLM Math , aka Riley Goodside‚Äôs ‚Äú You Can‚Äôt Do Math ‚Äù REPL-in-the-loop ( PR #8 ) *  Self-Ask With Search , Ofir Press‚Äô agent pattern ( PR #9 ) (later  ReAct, PR #24 ) *  NatBot , Nat Friedman‚Äôs browser controlling agent ( PR #18 ) * Adapters for  OpenAI, Cohere, and HuggingFaceHub All this was built and launched in a few days from Oct 16-25, 2022.  Turning research ideas/exciting usecases into software quickly and often  has been in the LangChain DNA from Day 1 and likely a big driver of LangChain‚Äôs success, to date amassing the largest community of AI Engineers and being the default launch framework for every big name from  Nvidia  to  OpenAI : Dancing with Giants But AI Engineering is built atop of constantly moving tectonic shifts:  *  ChatGPT  launched in November (‚Äú The Day the AGI Was Born ‚Äù) and the  API  released in March. Before the ChatGPT API, OpenAI did not have a chat endpoint. In order to build a chatbot with history, you had to make sure to chain all messages and prompt for completion. LangChain made it easy to do that out of the box, which was a huge driver of usage.  * Today, OpenAI has gone all-in on the chat API and is  deprecating the old completions models , essentially baking in the chat pattern as the default way most engineers should interact with LLMs‚Ä¶ and reducing (but not eliminating) the value of  ConversationChains . * And there have been more updates since:  Plugins  released in API form as  Functions  in June ( one of our top pods ever ‚Ä¶ reducing but not eliminating the value of  OutputParsers ) and  Finetuning   in August   (arguably reducing some need for  Retrieval  and  Prompt tooling ).  With each update, OpenAI and other frontier model labs realign the roadmaps of this nascent industry, and Harrison credits the modular design of LangChain in staying relevant. LangChain has not been merely responsive either: LangChain  added Agents  in November, well before they became  the hottest topic of the AI Summer , and now  Agents  feature as one of LangChain‚Äôs top two usecases.  LangChain‚Äôs problem for podcasters and newcomers alike is its sheer scope - it is the world‚Äôs most complete AI framework, but it also has a sprawling surface area that is difficult to fully grasp or document in one sitting. This means it‚Äôs time for the trademark Latent Space move ( ChatGPT ,  GPT4 ,  Auto-GPT , and Code Interpreter Advanced Data Analysis  GPT4.5 ):  the executive summary ! What is   LangChain? As Harrison explains,  LangChain is an open source framework for building  context-aware  reasoning applications,  available in Python and JS/TS. It launched in Oct 2022 with the central value proposition of ‚Äú composability ‚Äù, aka the idea that every AI engineer will want to switch LLMs, and combine LLMs with other things into ‚Äú chains ‚Äù, using a flexible  interface  that can be saved via a  schema . Today, LangChain‚Äôs principal offerings can be grouped as: *  Components : isolated modules/abstractions *  Model I/O *  Models  (for LLM/Chat/Embeddings, from OpenAI, Anthropic, Cohere, etc) *  Prompts  (Templates, ExampleSelectors, OutputParsers) *  Retrieval  ( revised and reintroduced in March ) *  Document Loaders  (eg from CSV, JSON, Markdown, PDF) *  Text Splitters  (15+ various strategies for chunking text to fit token limits) *  Retrievers  (generic interface for turning an unstructed query into a set of documents - for  self-querying ,  contextual compression ,  ensembling ) *  Vector Stores  ( retrievers  that search by similarity of embeddings) *  Indexers  (sync documents from any source into a  vector store  without duplication) *  Memory  (for long running chats, whether a simple  Buffer, Knowledge Graph, Summary, or Vector Store ) *  Use-Cases:  compositions of Components *  Chains : combining a PromptTemplate, LLM Model and optional OutputParser * with  Router, Sequential, and Transform Chains  for advanced usecases * savable, sharable schemas that can be  loaded from LangChainHub *  Agents : a chain that has access to a suite of tools, of nondeterministic length because the LLM is used as a reasoning engine to determine which actions to take and in which order. Notable  100LOC explainer here . *  Tools  (interfaces that an agent can use to interact with the world -  preset list here . Includes things like ChatGPT plugins, Google Search, WolframAlpha. Groups of tools are bundled up as  toolkits ) *  AgentExecutor  (the agent runtime, basically the while loop, with support for  controls ,  timeouts ,  memory sharing , etc) * LangChain has also added a  Callbacks  system for instrumenting each stage of LLM, Chain, and Agent calls (which enables  LangSmith , LangChain‚Äôs first cloud product), and most recently an  Expression Language , a declarative way to compose chains. LangChain the company incorporated in January 2023,  announced their seed round in April , and  launched LangSmith in July . At time of writing, the company has  93k followers ,  their Discord  has 31k members and their  weekly webinars  are attended by thousands of people live. The full-featuredness of LangChain means it is often  the first starting point for building any mainstream LLM use case , because they are most likely to have working guides for the new developer. Logan ( our first guest !) from OpenAI has been a notable fan of both  LangChain  and  LangSmith  (they will be running the first LangChain + OpenAI workshop at AI Eng Summit).  However, LangChain is not without its critics, with  Aravind Srinivas ,  Jim Fan ,  Max Woolf ,  Mckay Wrigley  and the  general Reddit/HN community  describing  frustrations with the value of their abstractions , and many are attempting to write their own (the common experience of adding and then removing LangChain is something we covered in  our Agents writeup ). Harrison compares this with the timeless ORM debate on the value of abstractions. LangSmith Last month, Harrison launched  LangSmith , their LLM observability tool and first cloud product. LangSmith makes it easy to monitor all the different primitives that LangChain offers (agents, chains, LLMs) as well as making it easy to  share  and evaluate them both through heuristics (i.e. manually written ones) and ‚ÄúLLM evaluating LLM‚Äù flows.  The  top HN comment  in the ‚ÄúLangChain is Pointless‚Äù thread observed that orchestration is the smallest part of the work, and the bulk of it is prompt tuning and data serialization. When asked this directly our pod, Harrison agreed: ‚ÄúI agree that those are big pain points that get exacerbated when you have these complex chains and agents where you can't really see what's going on inside of them. And I think that's partially why we built Langsmith‚Ä¶‚Äù  (48min mark) You can watch the full launch on the LangChain YouTube: It‚Äôs clear that the target audience for LangChain is expanding to folks who are building complex, production applications rather than focusing on the simpler ‚ÄúQ&A your docs‚Äù use cases that made it popular in the first place. As the AI Engineer space matures, there will be more and more tools graduating from supporting ‚Äúhobby‚Äù projects to more enterprise-y use cases.  In this episode we run through some of the history of LangChain, how it‚Äôs growing from an open source project to one of the highest valued AI startups out there, and its future. We hope you enjoy it! Show Notes *  LangChain *  LangChain‚Äôs Berkshire Hathaway Homepage *  Abstractions tweet *  LangSmith *  LangSmith Cookbooks  repo *  LangChain Retrieval  blog *  Evaluating CSV Question/Answering  blog and  YouTube *  MultiOn Partner  blog *  Harvard Sports Analytics Collective *  Evaluating RAG Webinar * awesome-langchain: *  LLM Math Chain *  Self-Ask *  LangChain Hub UI *  ‚ÄúLangChain is Pointless‚Äù * Harrison‚Äôs links *  sports - estimating player compatibility in the NBA *  early interest in prompt injections *  GitHub *  Twitter
timestamps: * [00:00:00] Introduction * [00:00:48] Harrison's background and how sports led him into ML * [00:04:54] The inspiration for creating LangChain - abstracting common patterns seen in other GPT-3 projects * [00:05:51] Overview of LangChain - a framework for building context-aware reasoning applications * [00:10:09] Components of LangChain - modules, chains, agents, etc. * [00:14:39] Underappreciated parts of LangChain - text splitters, retrieval algorithms like self-query * [00:18:46] Hiring at LangChain * [00:20:27] Designing the LangChain architecture - balancing flexibility and structure * [00:24:09] The difference between chains and agents in LangChain * [00:25:08] Prompt engineering and LangChain * [00:26:16] Announcing LangSmith * [00:30:50] Writing custom evaluators in LangSmith * [00:33:19] Reducing hallucinations - fixing retrieval vs generation issues * [00:38:17] The challenges of long context windows * [00:40:01] LangChain's multi-programming language strategy * [00:45:55] Most popular LangChain blog posts - deep dives into specific topics * [00:50:25] Responding to LangChain criticisms * [00:54:11] Harrison's advice to AI engineers * [00:55:43] Lightning Round
ai_summary:
The podcast features Alessio, a partner and CTO at Residence at Decibel Partners, and Swyx, founder of Smol.ai, as they interview Harrison Chase. Harrison, who has a background in Stats and CS from Harvard, delved into machine learning through sports analytics and eventually founded LangChain.

LangChain, initiated around November 2022, aims at creating context-aware reasoning applications by integrating various components and modules like prompt templates, language models, vector stores, and more. It was designed to cater to the evolving landscape of AI and generative models, providing developers a framework to build LLM applications effectively. One significant aspect of LangChain is its emphasis on being a 'Switzerland' in developer land, supporting multiple vector databases and AI models to prevent developers from getting locked into a single provider.

Additionally, Harrison discusses the concept of agents within LangChain, differentiating them from chains by their ability to decide the order of operations, thereby handling long-tail events efficiently. This approach facilitates more complex, context-aware applications.

LangSmith, another project by Harrison, serves as a control center for LLM applications, focusing on debugging, monitoring, logging, and evaluating these applications to enhance their performance and reliability.

Moreover, Harrison emphasizes the importance of building and experimenting in the rapidly evolving AI space, suggesting that engaging with cutting-edge technologies and concepts can lead to significant innovations or, at the very least, a deeper understanding of the field.
key_insights:
1. The importance of sports analytics as an entryway to data science and machine learning, offering quick feedback and real-world application.
2. AI applications in sports betting and financial predictions.
3. Harrison Chase's GPT aha moment stemmed from a hackathon project involving a bot for querying Notion and Slack, using GPT-3.
4. LangChain's conceptualization was prompted by identifying common abstractions in generative AI space during the period between Stable Diffusion and ChatGPT.
5. LangChain operates as a framework for building context-aware reasoning applications, streamlining the development process by providing components and modules for specific AI functionalities.
6. The evolution of LangChain included improving developer experience with OpenAI's chat API and incorporating feedback for enhancing LangChain's utility.
7. The LangChain Expression Language was introduced to allow for composability and flexibility in building AI applications.
8. Challenges in AI development include balancing complexity with user-friendliness, addressing hallucination (inaccurate AI outputs), and ensuring accurate memory in long conversations.
9. The potential shift in AI development practices with the advent of local models and multimodal AI capabilities.
10. Continuous feedback and community engagement significantly guide LangChain's development focus and feature prioritization.
quotes:
Given the extensive conversation, here are several actionable quotes that may impact the thinking or behavior of an AI engineer:

1. "I think sports is a great entryway for kind of like data science." - [00:02:43] 
   This quote emphasizes the practical applications of sports analytics as a gateway to data science and machine learning, encouraging AI engineers to consider unconventional pathways into their field.

2. "LangChain's a framework for building context-aware reasoning applications." - [00:08:14] 
   This statement underlines the core purpose of LangChain, suggesting AI engineers focus on developing applications that are not just intelligent but contextually aware, potentially guiding their approach in creating more nuanced AI solutions.

3. "I think accuracy is definitely the top that we're seeing right now." - [00:31:13] 
   Highlighting accuracy as a primary concern in the AI field, this quote may drive AI engineers to prioritize the accuracy of their models and applications, ensuring that they deliver reliable and trustworthy AI services.

4. "Build as many things as possible." - [00:54:11] 
   This advice encourages AI engineers to engage actively in building and experimenting with AI technologies, emphasizing the importance of hands-on experience and exploration in driving innovation and understanding in the rapidly evolving field of AI.

5. "Just build." - [01:00:49] 
   A succinct call to action for AI engineers, this quote reinforces the message that the best way to progress and innovate within AI is by actively engaging in the creation and development of new technologies and applications.

These quotes collectively emphasize the importance of practical experience, innovative application development, accuracy in AI solutions, and the potential of unconventional entry points into data science and AI. They could guide AI engineers in their approach to learning, prioritization, and technology development strategies.

title: RWKV: Reinventing RNNs for the Transformer Era ‚Äî with Eugene Cheah of UIlicious
author: Eugene Cheah
intro: The AI Engineer Summit Expo has been  announced , presented by AutoGPT (and future guest  Toran Bruce-Richards !) Stay tuned for more updates on  the Summit livestream  and  Latent Space University . This post was on  HN for 10 hours . What comes after the Transformer?  This is one of the  Top 10 Open Challenges in LLM Research  that has been the talk of the AI community this month. Jon Frankle ( friend of the show !) has an ongoing  bet  with Sasha Rush on whether  Attention is All You Need , and the most significant challenger to emerge this year has been  RWKV - Receptance Weighted Key Value models , which revive the RNN for GPT-class LLMs, inspired by a 2021 paper on  Attention Free Transformers  from Apple (surprise!). What this means practically is that RWKV models tend to scale in all directions (both in training and inference) much better than Transformers-based open source models: While remaining competitive on standard reasoning benchmarks: swyx was recently in Singapore for meetings with  AI government and industry folks , and grabbed 2 hours with RWKV committee member Eugene Cheah for a deep dive, the full recording of which is now up on  Latent Space TV : Today we release both the 2hr video and an edited 1hr audio version, to cater to the different audiences and provide ‚Äúablation opportunities‚Äù on RWKV interest level. The Eleuther Mafia? The RWKV project is notable not merely because of the credible challenge to the Transformers dominance. It is also a distributed, international, mostly uncredentialed community reminiscent of early 2020s Eleuther AI: * Primarily Discord, pseudonymous,  GPU-poor  volunteer community somehow coordinating enough to train >10B, OPT/BLOOM-competitive models * Being driven by the needs of its community, it is extremely polyglot (e.g. English, Chinese, Japanese, Arabic) not because it needs to beat some benchmarks, but because its users want it to be for their own needs. * ‚ÄúOpen Source‚Äù in both the good and the bad way - properly Apache 2.0 licensed ( not ‚Äúopen but restricted ‚Äù), yet trained on data taken from commercially compromised sources like the Pile (where  Shawn Presser‚Äôs Books3 dataset has been recently taken down ) and Alpaca (taking from  Steven Tey‚Äôs ShareGPT  which is technically against OpenAI TOS) The threadboi class has loved tracking the diffusion of Transformers paper authors out into the industry: But perhaps the underdog version of this is tracking the emerging Eleuther AI mafia: It will be fascinating to see how both Eleuther and Eleuther alums fare as they build out the future of both LLMs and open source AI. Audio Version
timestamps: assisted by  smol-podcaster . Different timestamps vs the 2hr YouTube * [00:05:35] Eugene's path into AI at UIlicious * [00:07:33] Tokenizer penalty and data efficiency of Transformers * [00:08:02] Using Salesforce CodeGen * [00:10:17] The limitations of Transformers for handling large context sizes * [00:13:17] RWKV compute costs compared to Transformers * [00:16:06] How Eugene found RWKV early * [00:18:52] RWKV's focus on supporting many languages, not just English * [00:21:24] Using the RWKV model for fine-tuning for specific languages * [00:24:45] What is RWKV? * [00:33:46] Overview of the different RWKV models like World, Raven, Novel * [00:41:34] Background of Blink, the creator of RWKV * [00:49:55] The linear vs quadratic scaling of RWKV vs Transformers * [00:53:29] RWKV matching Transformer performance on reasoning tasks * [00:54:31] The community's lack of marketing for RWKV * [00:57:00] The English-language bias in AI models * [01:00:33] Plans to improve RWKV's memory and context handling * [01:03:10] Advice for AI engineers wanting to get more technical knowledge Show Notes Companies/Organizations: * RWKV -  HF blog ,  paper ,  docs ,  GitHub ,  Huggingface * Raven 14B (finetuned on Alpaca+ShareGPT+...)  Demo * World 7B (supports 100+ world languages)  Demo *  How RWKV works in 100 LOC ,  RWKV overview *  EleutherAI  - Decentralized open source AI research group *  Stability AI  - Creators of Stable Diffusion  *  Conjecture  - Spun off from EleutherAI People: * Eugene Chia - CTO of  UIlicious , member of RWKV committee ( GitHub ,  Twitter ) *  Blink/Bo Peng  - Creator of RWKV architecture *  Quentin Anthony  - our Latent Space pod on Eleuther, coauthor on RWKV  *  Sharif Shameem  - our Latent Space pod on being early to Stable Diffusion *  Tri Dao  - our Latent Space pod on FlashAttention making Attention subquadratic *  Linus Lee  - our Latent Space pod in NYC *  Jonathan Frankle  - our Latent Space pod about Transformers longevity *  Chris Re  - Genius at Stanford working on state-space models * Andrej Karpathy -  Zero to Hero  series * Justine Tunney (" Justine.lol ") -  mmap trick Models/Papers: *  Top 10 Open Challenges in LLM Research *  Retentive Network: A Successor to Transformer for Large Language Models   *  GPT-NeoX  - Open source replica of GPT-3 by EleutherAI  *  Salesforce CodeGen  and  CodeGen 2 *  Attention Free Transformers paper *  The Pile *  RedPajama dataset *  Monarch Mixer -  Revisiting BERT, Without Attention or MLPs Misc Notes RWKV is not without known weaknesses - Transformers do well in reasoning because they are  expressive in the forward pass , yet the RWKV docs already note that it is  sensitive to prompt formatting and poor at lookback tasks . We also asked pointed questions about RWKV‚Äôs challenges in the full podcast.   Get full access to Latent Space at  www.latent.space/subscrib

title: Cursor.so: The AI-first Code Editor ‚Äî with Aman Sanger of Anysphere
author: Aman Sanger
intro: Thanks to the almost 30k people  who tuned in to  the last episode ! Your podcast cohosts have been busy shipping: *  Alessio open sourced  smol-podcaster , which makes the show notes here!  *  swyx  launched   GodMode . Maybe someday the Cursor of browsers? *  We‚Äôre also helping organize a  Llama Finetuning Hackameetup  this Saturday in anticipation of the  CodeLlama  release.  Lastly, more speakers were  announced  at  AI Engineer Summit ! üëÄ ~46%  of code typed through VS Code is written by Copilot.  How do we get closer to 90+%?  Aman Sanger  says we need a brand new  AI-powered IDE  to get there; and we‚Äôre excited to be the first podcast  ever  to tell the  Cursor  story. If you haven‚Äôt heard of Cursor, you may have been living under a rock. Here are just some of the rave reviews going around in  the past week alone : * ‚ÄúCursor is the best product I've used in a while‚Äù -  Alex MacCaw * ‚ÄúSomeone finally put GPT into a code editor in a seamless way. It's so elegant and easy. No more copying and pasting.‚Äù -  Andrew McCalip * ‚ÄúCoding with AI is getting insane.‚Äù -  Mckay Wrigley * ‚ÄúThis is mind blowing ü§Ø‚Äù -  Linus Ekenstam * ‚ÄúCursor + gpt4-32k = illegal levels of productivity‚Äù -  Sully Omarr * ‚ÄúEL MEJOR EDITOR DE C√ìDIGO con IA‚Äù -  Carlos Santana A decade ago, ‚Äúplatform risk‚Äù meant building apps on social media platforms was risky as you could get cut off from the social network.  Today, the AI version of ‚Äúplatform risk‚Äù is building AI products within an existing product (like an AI extension for VS Code, or a Figma plugin). Since Copilot, a generation of VSCode plugins have launched (including  Cody ,  Cosine , and previous guests  Codeium  and  Codium ), only to be challenged by  Copilot X  itself. A core AI Engineering thesis is that  new capabilities in AI demands  new innovation in AI UX  (and that  AI UX can actually be a viable moat ) .  Take VS Code for example; when Github was first working on Copilot, there was actually no way to support the ‚Äúghost autocomplete‚Äù feature we all use today. They eventually convinced the team to build it, and Copilot‚Äôs success speaks for itself. If you‚Äôre a startup building on top of VSC today, you do not have the same access and influence on the roadmap.  Your UX is limited to what they allow you to do, and often that caps your ability to successfully compete against them.   Since Cursor owns the whole IDE, they can do things you can‚Äôt (yet) do in VSCode: Cursor‚Äôs Gameplan Cursor is competing head to head against VS Code by forking Microsoft‚Äôs IDE and building their own AI-powered version. A few of Cursor‚Äôs unique features: *  Native chat:  Chat is a core piece of Cursor. Users can choose between GPT-3.5 and GPT-4 to ask questions and receive answers based on their code. *  ‚ÄúMentioning‚Äù files:  you can easily add files into your request context by using ‚Äú@‚Äù; this works both for code as well as documentation. If you want to do a change that includes multiple files, you can include them in your question to make sure the change is reflected in all of them. *  Custom prompting engine:  Cursor built  Priompt , their custom prompting engine. As your chats go over the context window size, Priompt figures out which messages to keep in the history, which files to drop from the prompt, etc.  *  Moving beyond typing:  while IDEs are familiar to folks as today‚Äôs interfaces, in the future Cursor hopes to have agents you can delegate tasks to. Instead of a back and forth on a new feature or bug fix, you can ask it to do the whole thing for you end to end. After diving deep into Cursor we nerded out on model usage, training, quantization, and evaluation. There‚Äôs a ton of great content in this episode, we hope you‚Äôll enjoy it! As always, feedback welcome in the comments, and tag us on socials for future guest suggestions! Show Notes *  Cursor *  Gary Marcus‚Äô cubes prompt *  Priompt *  ‚ÄúHumans should focus on bigger problems.‚Äù *  Codium AI on Latent Space *  Rift from Morph *  Sourcegraph *  E2B *  Repl.it *  HungryHungryHippos, Hyena, etc (see our FlashAttention episode) * Aman Tweets *  Why GPT-3.5 is (mostly) cheaper than Llama 2 *  Llama‚Äôs architectural limitations * ‚ÄúTraining will look like researchers/practitioners offloading large-scale training jobs to specialized ‚Äútraining‚Äù companies: a state of the world that resembles chip design & fabrication.‚Äù -  Mosaic prediction * ‚ÄúThe size of all code/history on Github public repos is 92TB. The size of Google's monorepo in 2015 was 86TB (of much higher quality code). If Google were willing to deploy code models trained on their own data, they'd have a noticable advantage over everyone else.‚Äù -  May 2023
timestamps: * [00:00:00] Intros * [00:02:31] Developing CAD models vs coding models * [00:05:23] Deciding to build a new IDE optimized for large language models * [00:10:50] Getting early access to GPT-4 and realizing its potential for software development * [00:12:32] Rethinking the UI/UX for coding * [00:18:24] Cursor's features like system prompts and chat * [00:22:24] Tips for prompting GPT-3/4 for code generation and editing * [00:27:24] Cursor's documentation and context features * [00:29:30] The potential of coding agents like Code Interpreter * [00:38:23] Cursor's internal prompting tool Priompt * [00:40:47] The challenges of very long context lengths for models * [00:45:44] The compute costs for prompt tokens vs. completion tokens * [00:49:36] How quantization interacts with model utilization * [00:51:24] Issues with human eval for benchmarking code models * [00:53:12] Thoughts on training models vs. relying on foundation models from big providers * [00:55:34] The origin story of Cursor's parent company AnySphere * [00:56:00] Lightning Round
ai_summary:
In this episode of the Latent Space podcast, hosts Alessio and Swyx welcome guest Aman Sanger. Sanger shares his journey through the tech and AI industry, having worked at companies like Gamelon, Bridgewater, McKinsey, Google, and You.com, and founding his consultancy, Abelian AI. He highlights his academic background in computer science and math from MIT and discusses his involvement in projects such as Instill and his latest venture, Cursor.so.

A personal tidbit Sanger shares is his passion for squash, a sport he played competitively in high school. This competitive nature, he notes, translates into his work ethic and approach to his startups, emphasizing a strong dislike for losing.

The conversation then delves into Sanger's decision to launch Instill and the subsequent focus shift to Cursor.so, exploring its development from his fascination with AI and collaborative experiences at MIT. He details the technical challenges and breakthroughs in AI and CAD (Computer-Aided Design) software, underscoring the limitations they encountered with model training and inference and the eventual realization that a new approach to CAD and software development was necessary.

Sanger elaborates on the technological advancements and the potential of AI in optimizing mechanical engineering design processes, his pragmatic take on competition, and the importance of being a user of the product you're building. This led to the pivot towards developing Cursor.so, a product propelled by the capabilities of GPT-4 predicting a future where software development would undergo a significant transformation tailored by AI advancements.

The discussion wraps up with insights into Cursor.so's features, including code editing, documentation integration, and the development team's future endeavors to enhance AI-driven coding tools. Sanger's perspective on the evolving landscape of AI in software development highlights the significance of continuous innovation and the impact of competitive and user-centric approaches in the tech industry.
key_insights:
1. Development of a transformer model trained for CAD (computer-aided design) data to aid mechanical engineers by predicting next steps in part design, but encountered limitations due to insufficient data volume and poor spatial reasoning capabilities of current models.
2. Observation that large-scale text models like GBD4 show advantages in software development tasks, including code refactoring and debugging, indicating a future where the majority of coding could be automated.
3. Introduction of Cursor, a product offering a novel IDE experience to support software development with advanced AI integrations, emphasizing the necessity of redesigning the software development UX to leverage evolving large language models.
4. Early access to GPT-4 highlighted its superior performance in code-related tasks compared to its predecessors and open-source models, suggesting a significant leap in AI's capability to understand and generate code.
5. Cursor's approach to enhancing the coding experience includes an internal tool called Priompt for advanced prompt construction and the possibility of integrating fine-tuned models for specific tasks or domains.
6. AnySphere, the company behind Cursor, aims to reshape software development by enabling more intuitive interactions with AI for coding tasks, suggesting a future where AI plays a central role in software creation and maintenance.
quotes:
Below are selected actionable quotes from Aman Sanger that might impact the thinking or behavior of an AI Engineer:

1. **On competitive nature in startups** (timecode [00:02:17]):
   - "I'm very competitive. I really hate losing...the competitive nature, I think it in general helps motivate me and makes me, I guess, just work harder."
   
2. **On moving off a project due to technical challenges** (timecode [00:07:52]):
   - "If you try to test these models today...it's clear that these models are not that good at spatial reasoning, and that's exactly what's needed for CAD."

3. **On the future of AI-powered CAD software** (timecode [00:08:47]):
   - "I think the best way here is probably redesigning the entire system...it feels like with the advancements you have in kind of text to images, and there's some new companies kind of doing stuff with text to 3D, it feels like the reasonable approach is actually just scrap the way that people are doing CAD right now."

4. **On the insight gained from early access to GPT-4** (timecode [00:10:54]):
   - "And before everyone started talking about it and knowing about it, we kind of pasted it in and it got 85%. And we were just like, wow, best open source model at the time got 30%...These models are just going to get better and better and better at programming."

5. **On owning the full IDE for developing AI tools** (timecode [00:12:32]):
   - "You need to own the full IDE and completely redesign the flow of producing software and just doing software development in general."

6. **On AI model training observations** (timecode [00:14:12]):
   - "I think I have some thoughts on this because there's the whole thing with chinchilla scaling and then people are now saying, oh, chinchilla scaling doesn't matter because of inference."

7. **On the importance of direct involvement in the products you develop** (timecode [00:19:17]):
   - "We learned this from CAD, and we strongly believe this now that it is much better to be a user of the product you're building."

8. **On the future of coding tools and IDEs** (timecode [00:27:36]):
   - "So one thing that our users have found quite helpful is being able to add files or add documentation...it's stored locally for you."

9. **On the approach towards developing better AI tools for coding** (timecode [00:29:30]):
    - "I think it's pretty important to kind of have the agent do these very small, discrete units and then show the output in a way that's very easy for the user to understand and then go in and fix."

These quotes can guide AI engineers both in their technical approaches and their strategic directions in building the next generation of AI tools and platforms.

title: The Mathematics of Training LLMs ‚Äî with Quentin Anthony of Eleuther AI
author: Quentin Anthony
intro: Invites are going out for  AI Engineer Summit ! In the meantime, we have just announced our first  Actually Open AI event  with Brev.dev and Langchain, Aug 26 in our SF HQ (we‚Äôll record talks for those remote). See you soon (and join the Discord)! Special thanks to  @nearcyan  for helping us arrange this with the Eleuther team. This post was on the  HN frontpage  for 15 hours. As startups and even VCs  hoard GPUs  to attract talent,  the one thing more valuable than GPUs is knowing how to use them  (aka,  make  GPUs go brrrr ). There is an incredible amount of  tacit knowledge  in the NLP community around training, and until Eleuther.ai came along you pretty much had to work at Google or Meta to gain that knowledge. This makes it hard for non-insiders to even do simple estimations around costing out projects - it is well known how to trade $ for GPU hours, but trading ‚Äú$ for size of model‚Äù or ‚Äú$ for quality of model‚Äù is less known and more valuable and full of opaque ‚Äúit depends‚Äù. This is why  rules of thumb for training  are incredibly useful, because they cut through the noise and give you the simple 20% of knowledge that determines 80% of the outcome derived from hard earned experience. Today‚Äôs guest, Quentin Anthony from EleutherAI, is one of the top researchers in  high-performance deep learning . He‚Äôs one of the co-authors of  Transformers Math 101 , which was one of the clearest articulations of training rules of thumb. We can think of no better way to dive into training math than to have Quentin run us through a masterclass on model weights, optimizer states, gradients, activations, and how they all impact memory requirements. The core equation you will need to know is the following: Where  C  is the compute requirements to train a model,  P  is the number of parameters, and  D  is the size of the training dataset in tokens. This is also equal to  œÑ , the throughput of your machine measured in FLOPs (Actual FLOPs/GPU * # of GPUs), multiplied by  T , the amount of time spent training the model. Taking Chinchilla scaling at face value, you can simplify this equation to be `C = 120(P^2)`.These laws are only true when 1000 GPUs for 1 hour costs the same as 1 GPU for 1000 hours, so it‚Äôs not always that easy to make these assumptions especially when it comes to communication overhead.   There‚Äôs a lot more math to dive into here between training and inference, which you can listen to in the episode or read in the articles.  The other interesting concept we covered is distributed training and strategies such as ZeRO and 3D parallelism. As these models have scaled, it‚Äôs become impossible to fit everything in a single GPU for training and inference. We leave these advanced concepts to the end, but there‚Äôs a lot of innovation happening around sharding of params, gradients, and optimizer states that you must know is happening in modern LLM training.  If you have questions, you can join the  Eleuther AI Discord  or follow  Quentin on Twitter .  Show Notes *  Transformers Math 101 Article *  Eleuther.ai *  GPT-NeoX 20B *  BLOOM *  Turing NLG *  Mosaic *  Oak Ridge & Frontier Supercomputer *  Summit Supercomputer  *  Lawrence Livermore Lab *  RWKV *  Flash Attention  *  Stas Bekman
timestamps: * [00:00:00] Quentin's background and work at Eleuther.ai * [00:03:14] Motivation behind writing the Transformers Math 101 article * [00:05:58] Key equation for calculating compute requirements (tau x T = 6 x P x D) * [00:10:00] Difference between theoretical and actual FLOPs * [00:12:42] Applying the equation to estimate compute for GPT-3 training * [00:14:08] Expecting 115+ teraflops/sec per A100 GPU as a baseline * [00:15:10] Tradeoffs between Nvidia and AMD GPUs for training * [00:18:50] Model precision (FP32, FP16, BF16 etc.) and impact on memory * [00:22:00] Benefits of model quantization even with unlimited memory * [00:23:44] KV cache memory overhead during inference * [00:26:08] How optimizer memory usage is calculated * [00:32:03] Components of total training memory (model, optimizer, gradients, activations) * [00:33:47] Activation recomputation to reduce memory overhead * [00:38:25] Sharded optimizers like ZeRO to distribute across GPUs * [00:40:23] Communication operations like scatter and gather in ZeRO * [00:41:33] Advanced 3D parallelism techniques (data, tensor, pipeline) * [00:43:55] Combining 3D parallelism and sharded optimizers * [00:45:43] Challenges with heterogeneous clusters for distribution * [00:47:58] Lightning Round
ai_summary:
In the Latent Space podcast episode, hosts Alessio and Swyx discuss Transformers and AI training with special guest Quentin Anthony from Eleuther.ai. Quentin, a PhD student involved with Eleuther during the training of the GPT-NeoX20B model, shares insights on the challenges of scaling AI models, including communication costs and the synchronization needed to make use of hundreds of GPUs efficiently. The discussion explores the motivation behind writing a blog post titled "Transformers Math 101" by Eleuther, aiming to clarify the more practical, nitty-gritty details of AI training and inference that are often overlooked in theoretical discussions, through sharing notes and findings within Eleuther‚Äôs open research approach.

The podcast delves into various technical aspects of AI training, including the importance of mixed precision training (using combinations of FP16, BF16, and FP32), the memory constraints imposed by model weights, optimizer states, gradients, and activation memory, and strategies to efficiently use GPU resources. Quentin emphasizes that activation memory management during training can sometimes lead to memory issues due to its dynamic nature, and strategies like activation recomputation can help manage memory more effectively.

The conversation also covers distributed training tactics, including 'Zero', which involves sharding optimizer states across GPUs, and '3D Parallelism', a combination of data parallelism, tensor parallelism, and pipeline parallelism to optimize training across multiple GPUs. Quentin points out challenges with adapting models to multimodal parallelism and reinforcement learning due to their unique training and inference requirements. 

Quentin and the hosts also touch on future directions and unsolved problems in AI, noting the importance of research into on-the-fly communication compression and efficient parallelism strategies for multimodal models and reinforcement learning.

Listeners are encouraged to explore the blog post ‚ÄúTransformers Math 101‚Äù for a deeper understanding and insights shared during the podcast episode.
key_insights:
1. Importance of understanding the details of AI training and inference for optimal performance on hardware.
2. EleutherAI's commitment to sharing technical knowledge and insights, which is rare in proprietary research environments.
3. The cognitive cost model for training Transformer models is based on the hardware setup throughput and the time spent.
4. The relevance of the token-parameter ratio in dataset for determining the model size, influenced by research like the Chinchilla paper.
5. The actual versus theoretical flops in training AI models, emphasizing the gap due to hardware utilization efficiency.
6. Utilization of cloud instances and computing resources requires considering the cost and time alongside model and hardware specifications.
7. Challenges in scaling AI models across multiple GPUs due to communication costs and synchronization issues.
8. The shift from FP32 to mixed precision (FP16 and BF16) in deep learning to improve performance, and eventual movement towards even lower precision.
9. The necessity of memory-efficient techniques in training, such as optimizer state sharding and activation recomputation to manage large models.
10. Insights into distributed training strategies, including shard optimizers and 3D parallelism, for efficient AI model training.
quotes:
**[00:08:34] Quentin:** "I always feel like you should go with the minimum number of GPUs because the more number of GPUs that you have, the more likely it is for things to break. So I would say just find out what time is reasonable for you and then fit the number of GPUs to that and no more. Because people get greedy and they say, if I have twice the GPUs, I can get this done in half the time. And then you end up taking three times the time because everything is breaking every day. And that's when I am up at midnight trying to fix your model that's broken."

**[00:14:44] Quentin:** "For a number like that, we basically, we compared a lot of different frameworks ... and we saw across a bunch of different hardware configurations that if you tune things correctly, you should be getting above 115 in pretty much all cases. So like there are some cases where things are tuned poorly or your system is a little weird, but we've never been able to get a new system and not been able to get above 115. If something is below 115, you have something really wrong in your software."

**[00:28:22] Quentin:** "So I'm a systems guy. I'm an engineer. And a lot of these things come to me as magic. Adam comes to me as magic. I see it from the gods. I say, this is how a deep learning model is trained. And this is how the next step is calculated. And then I say, okay, how do I make that fast?"

**[00:32:03] Quentin:** "You don't want to store more than, you know, X-sized tensor. And some fall above that, some fall below it. And you're not trying to squeeze. You care more about getting something close enough to what the actual heuristic should be without actually computing the heuristic because you don't want to spend the time writing that heuristic code."

**[00:38:38] Quentin:** "I say 3D parallel gives you the most control and also the most ways to go wrong. And depending on whether you have more engineers or whether you have more GPUs, that should decide which of these you go with."

**[00:49:26] Quentin:** "...what I'm getting to is how should you compress your communication before it happens? So on the fly compression, you have some buffer that needs to be communicated. You compress it with a GPU kernel, then you send it across the network and then you decompress it ... Making people spend less money on communication fabrics and more on GPUs as intended is sort of a thing that people need to explore."

title: LLMs Everywhere: Running 70B models in browsers and iPhones using MLC ‚Äî with Tianqi Chen of CMU / OctoML
author: Tianqi Chen
intro: We have just announced our first set of speakers at  AI Engineer Summit ! Sign up for the livestream or email  sponsors@ai.engineer  if you‚Äôd like to support. We are facing a  massive GPU crunch . As both startups and VC‚Äôs hoard Nvidia GPUs like countries count nuclear stockpiles,  tweets about GPU shortages  have become increasingly common.  But what if we could run LLMs with AMD cards, or without a GPU at all?  There‚Äôs just one weird trick:  compilation.  And there‚Äôs one person uniquely qualified to do it. We had the pleasure to sit down with  Tianqi Chen , who‚Äôs an Assistant Professor at CMU, where he both teaches the  MLC course  and runs the MLC group. You might also know him as the creator of  XGBoost ,  Apache TVM , and  MXNet , as well as the co-founder of  OctoML .  The MLC (short for  Machine Learning Compilation ) group has released a lot of interesting projects: *  MLC Chat :  an iPhone app that lets you run models like RedPajama-3B and Vicuna-7B on-device. It gets up to 30 tok/s! *  Web LLM :  Run models like LLaMA-70B in your browser (!!) to offer local inference in your product. *  MLC LLM:   a framework that allows any language models to be deployed natively on different hardware and software stacks. The MLC group has  just announced  new support for AMD cards; we previously talked about the shortcomings of ROCm, but using MLC you can get performance very close to the NVIDIA‚Äôs counterparts. This is great news for founders and builders, as AMD cards are more readily available. Here are their latest results on AMD‚Äôs 7900s vs some of top NVIDIA consumer cards. If you just can‚Äôt get a GPU at all, MLC LLM also supports ARM and x86 CPU architectures as targets by leveraging LLVM. While speed performance isn‚Äôt comparable, it allows for non-time-sensitive inference to be run on commodity hardware. We also enjoyed getting a peek into TQ‚Äôs process, which  involves a lot of sketching : With all the other work going on in this space with projects like  ggml  and  Ollama , we‚Äôre excited to see GPUs becoming less and less of an issue to get models in the hands of more people, and innovative software solutions to hardware problems! Show Notes *  TQ‚Äôs Projects: *  XGBoost *  Apache TVM *  MXNet *  MLC *  OctoML *  CMU Catalyst *  ONNX *  GGML *  Mojo *  WebLLM *  RWKV *  HiPPO *  Tri Dao‚Äôs Episode *  George Hotz Episode People : *  Carlos Guestrin *  Albert Gu
timestamps: * [00:00:00] Intros * [00:03:41] The creation of XGBoost and its surprising popularity * [00:06:01] Comparing tree-based models vs deep learning * [00:10:33] Overview of TVM and how it works with ONNX * [00:17:18] MLC deep dive * [00:28:10] Using int4 quantization for inference of language models * [00:30:32] Comparison of MLC to other model optimization projects * [00:35:02] Running large language models in the browser with WebLLM * [00:37:47] Integrating browser models into applications * [00:41:15] OctoAI and self-optimizing compute * [00:45:45] Lightning Round
ai_summary:
The podcast episode features a conversation with Tianqi Chen (referred to as TQ), who is an assistant professor in Machine Learning Computer Science at CMU, a key figure at Catalyst Group, and the chief technologist of OctoML. TQ discusses his multi-faceted roles, particularly emphasizing his enthusiasm for open-source projects like Apache TVM, XGBoost, MXNet, and his habit of sketching design diagrams in sketchbooks to trace the evolution of his projects from ideas to implementation. The discussion delves into TQ's work on XGBoost, highlighting its creation as a byproduct of exploring alternatives to deep learning models and its subsequent popularity due to its effectiveness in machine learning competitions.

Further, TVM is discussed as a popular machine learning compilation framework aimed at optimizing model runtimes across various hardware platforms. The conversation also touches upon the merging of tree-based models and deep learning, the significance of machine learning compilation, comparisons with other projects like ggml and Mojo, and the challenges and advancements in making machine learning models more accessible and optimized for diverse computational environments, including browsers.

OctoAI, TQ's venture in creating a compute service focusing on model runtime optimization, is explored as a response to the evolving market demands wherein the shift towards utilizing pre-trained generative models presents new challenges in model deployment and efficiency. TQ emphasizes the importance of looking at machine learning systems from a holistic perspective, combining algorithm design, system optimization, and data curation to develop impactful AI applications. He expresses excitement for continuous learning and lifelong adaptation in AI, illustrating a vision for AI systems that evolve and adapt over time.
key_insights:
1. XGBoost emerged from the intention to explore alternatives to deep learning models and became popular for its efficiency and Python bindings, leading to widespread community contributions and improvements.
2. Tree-based models, including XGBoost, are preferred for tabular data due to their innate properties such as interpretability and automatic feature composition, offering a compelling alternative or complement to neural network approaches.
3. The development of TVM (Tensor Virtual Machine) was motivated by the challenges of optimizing deep learning models across different hardware platforms, aiming for a generic and automated solution for model compilation.
4. TVM's ability to take computational graphs and loop-level program representations, perform compiler optimizations, and generate portable low-level code facilitates efficient execution of machine learning models on diverse hardware.
5. MLC (Machine Learning Compilation) is emerging as a distinct field blending compiler optimizations with machine learning expertise, aiming to streamline the deployment and execution of models across various platforms effectively.
6. MLCLLM, building upon the principles of TVM, represents a focused effort in machine learning compilation, aiming to simplify capturing new models and applying optimizations for efficient deployment, including on mobile devices.
7. The push towards open-source AI research and development aims to foster a rich ecosystem where diverse models, from personal to large-scale generative models, can interact and augment each other, potentially leading to a more decentralized and vibrant AI future.
8. The intersection of machine learning system optimizations and algorithmic advancements signifies a holistic approach to AI development, emphasizing the importance of considering model architectures, systemic optimizations, and data processing in tandem for effective application deployment.
quotes:
[00:06:02] Alessio: "I'm always curious when it comes to these improvements, like, what's the design process in terms of like coming up with it? And how much of it is a collaborative with like other people that you're working with versus like trying to be, you know, obviously, in academia, it's like very paper-driven kind of research driven."

[00:21:52] Tianqi: "First of all, I do work with people working on compilation as well. So we're also taking inspirations from a lot of early innovations in the field. Like for example, TVM initially, we take a lot of inspirations from Halide, which is just an image processing compiler. And of course, since then, we have evolved quite a bit to focus on the machine learning related compilations."

[00:44:51] Tianqi: "So I think that there are engineering challenges on. In fact, first of all, you will need to be able to support all the kind of hardware backhand you have, right? On one hand, if you look at the media library, you'll find very surprisingly, not too surprisingly, most of the latest libraries works well on the latest GPU. But there are other GPUs out there in the cloud as well."

[00:50:29] Tianqi: "So I think all these things are interesting and relevant in here."

[00:51:35] Tianqi: "I think it's going to continue going to be more important in the future."

title: FlashAttention 2: making Transformers 800% faster w/o approximation - with Tri Dao of Together AI
author: Alessio Fanelli and Tri Dao
intro: FlashAttention was first published by Tri Dao in May 2022 and it had a deep impact in the large language models space. Most open models you‚Äôve heard of (RedPajama,  MPT ,  LLaMA , Falcon, etc) all leverage it for faster inference. Tri came on the podcast to chat about FlashAttention, the newly released FlashAttention-2, the research process at Hazy Lab, and more.    This is the first episode of¬†our ‚ÄúPapers Explained‚Äù series, which will cover some of the foundational research in this space. Our Discord also hosts a weekly Paper Club, which you can signup for  here .  How does FlashAttention work? The paper is titled ‚Äú FlashAttention: Fast and Memory-Efficient Exact Attention with IO-Awareness ‚Äù. There are a couple keywords to call out: *  ‚ÄúMemory Efficient‚Äù : standard attention memory usage is quadratic with sequence length (i.e. O(N^2)). FlashAttention is sub-quadratic at O(N).  *  ‚ÄúExact‚Äù : the opposite of ‚Äúexact‚Äù in this case is ‚Äúsparse‚Äù, as in ‚Äúsparse networks‚Äù (see our  episode with Jonathan Frankle  for more). This means that you‚Äôre not giving up any precision. * The ‚ÄúIO‚Äù in  ‚ÄúIO-Awareness‚Äù  stands for ‚ÄúInput/Output‚Äù and hints at a write/read related bottleneck.  Before we dive in, look at this simple GPU architecture diagram: The GPU has access to three memory stores at runtime: *  SRAM : this is on-chip memory co-located with the actual execution core. It‚Äôs limited in size (~20MB on an A100 card) but extremely fast (19TB/s total bandwidth) *  HBM:  this is off-chip but on-card memory, meaning it‚Äôs in the GPU but not co-located with the core itself. An A100 has 40GB of HBM, but only a 1.5TB/s bandwidth.  *  DRAM:  this is your traditional CPU RAM. You can have TBs of this, but you can only get ~12.8GB/s bandwidth, which is way too slow. Now that you know what HBM is, look at how the standard Attention algorithm is implemented: As you can see, all 3 steps include a ‚Äúwrite X to HBM‚Äù step and a ‚Äúread from HBM‚Äù step. The core idea behind FlashAttention boils down to this: instead of storing each intermediate result, why don‚Äôt we use kernel fusion and run every operation in a single kernel in order to avoid memory read/write overhead?  (We¬†also talked about kernel fusion in our episode with  George Hotz  and how PyTorch / tinygrad take different approaches here) The result is much faster, but much harder to read: As you can see, FlashAttention is a very meaningful speed improvement on traditional Attention, and it‚Äôs easy to understand why it‚Äôs becoming the standard for most models. This should be enough of a primer before you dive into our episode! We talked about FlashAttention-2, how Hazy Research Group works, and some of the research being done in Transformer alternatives. Show Notes: *  FlashAttention: Fast and Memory-Efficient Exact Attention with IO-Awareness   (arXiv) *  FlashAttention-2 *  Together AI *  From Deep Learning to Long Learning *  The Hardware Lottery by Sara Hooker *  Hazy Research *  Is Attention All You Need? *  Nvidia CUTLASS 3 *  SRAM scaling slows * Transformer alternatives: *  S4 *  Hyena *  Recurrent Neural Networks (RNNs)
timestamps: : * Tri's background [00:00:00] * FlashAttention‚Äôs deep dive [00:02:18] * How the Hazy Research group collaborates across theory, systems, and applications [00:17:21] * Evaluating models beyond raw performance [00:25:00] * FlashAttention-2 [00:27:00] * CUDA and The Hardware Lottery [00:30:00] * Researching in a fast-changing market [00:35:00] * Promising transformer alternatives like state space models and RNNs [00:37:30] * The spectrum of openness in AI models [00:43:00] * Practical impact of models like LLAMA2 despite restrictions [00:47:12] * Incentives for releasing open training datasets [00:49:43] * Lightning Round [00:53:22]
ai_summary:
In the Latent Space podcast episode, Alessio, Partner and CTO-in-Residence at Decibel Partners, hosts Tri Dao, a recent PhD graduate from Stanford and a major contributor to the FlashAttention paper. Tri is set to become an assistant professor in Computer Science at Princeton and has also joined Together as Chief Scientist, the company behind RedPajama.

Tri shares his academic journey, highlighting his initial aspiration to major in economics before switching to math upon his exposure to Stanford's curriculum. This decision pivoted his career towards mathematics, computer science, and AI research. The discussion transitions into Tri's work on FlashAttention and its latest iteration, FlashAttention 2. Tri explains the significance of these innovations in making transformer models more efficient by reducing the computational complexity from quadratic to linear with respect to the sequence length, thereby enabling faster processing and memory efficiency without compromising on the quality of attention mechanisms in AI models.

Furthermore, the conversation touches on the nuances of AI research and development, including the challenges of working with different hardware architectures and the importance of collaboration among academia, industry, and open-source communities to drive progress in AI technologies. They also explore potential future directions for model architectures beyond transformers, emphasizing the need for continuous exploration of alternative models and methods to enhance AI capabilities.

In sum, this episode covers Tri Dao's impactful work in AI research, particularly in improving transformer efficiency, his academic and career journey, and the broader context of AI development and its challenges.
key_insights:
1. FlashAttention improves transformer efficiency by making memory usage linear with sequence length, contrasting with traditional transformers' quadratic scaling.
2. Despite maintaining quadratic computational complexity, FlashAttention offers a 2-4x wall clock speed up by being more hardware-friendly.
3. FlashAttention avoids the trade-offs associated with approximate attention methods, offering exact results without compromising on model quality.
4. A significant innovation of FlashAttention is its IO (input/output) awareness, optimizing memory bandwidth usage‚Äîa limiting factor in scaling transformer models on current hardware architectures.
5. The discovery process for the core innovations behind FlashAttention involved merging ideas from both machine learning algorithms and systems optimization, particularly kernel fusion and online softmax trick for efficient computation.
6. Kernel fusion in FlashAttention combines operations to minimize memory read/writes but sacrifices some flexibility for researchers wanting to experiment with attention mechanisms.
7. Future hardware developments might not significantly expand SRAM, focusing instead on improving HBM (High Bandwidth Memory), which reinforces the need for algorithmic approaches that leverage memory asymmetry.
8. LLAMA2's release by Meta represents a significant step towards open-source AI, with the potential to shift the balance of power from proprietary models towards more openly available models that businesses and developers can fine-tune or modify.
9. There's an ongoing interest in exploring transformer alternatives for improved efficiency in handling long sequences or offering higher generation throughput, despite attention's current dominance.
10. The ecosystem benefits from open-source contributions across models, datasets, and innovations, with a community-driven approach to enhancing AI capabilities and accessibility.
quotes: "I would say try to understand both the algorithm and the systems that these algorithms run on. I think at the intersection of machine learning system has been really exciting, and there's been a lot of amazing results at this intersection. And then when you scale models to large scale, both the machine learning side and the system side really matter." [00:54:06] - Tri

title: Llama 2: The New Open LLM SOTA (ft. Nathan Lambert, Matt Bornstein, Anton Troynikov, Russell Kaplan, Whole Mars Catalog et al.)
author: Nathan Lambert, Simon Willison, Alex Volkov, Matt Bornstein, and Anton Troynikov
intro: As first discussed on our  May Emergency pod  and  leaked 4 days ago , Llama (renamed from LLaMA) was upgraded to Llama 2 (pretraining on  2 trillion tokens  with 2x the context length - bigger than any dataset discussed in  Datasets 101 , and adding  ~$20m  of RLHF/preference annotation) and released for commercial use on 18 July. It  immediately displaced Falcon-40B  as the leading open LLM and was immediately converted/ quantized to GGML  and other formats. Llama 2 seems to outperform all other open source models in their equivalent  weight class : Why are open models important ?  The intersection of Open Source and AI  is one of the oldest themes on this publication, and there has been a raging debate on the security and reliability of the OpenAI models and APIs. Users have reported  GPT-4‚Äôs quality going down , which has been  denied  and  denied  and as of today,  given some supporting data from Databricks , and complained about the  API reliability  and  rapid deprecation schedules . Last and surely the biggest, there are entire classes of businesses and government/healthcare/military organizations that categorically  cannot  send any of their sensitive data to an external API provider, even if it is OpenAI through Azure. The only way to have total control is to own and serve your own models, which Llama 2 now pushes forward in terms of the state of the art (your own GPT3.5-quality model, though it is nowhere near Claude 2 or GPT-4). As we do with breaking news, we got on to  Twitter Spaces again  to chat with two scheduled guests: * , ML Researcher at Huggingface and author of  Interconnects  who had  the best summary of the Llama2 paper *  Matt Bornstein , organizer of the a16z infra team that launched  Llama2.ai  ( source here ) and has been coding up a storm with  AI demo apps , unusual for VCs as well as  Anton Troynikov  of Chroma,  Russell Kaplan  of Scale AI, and Omar Qazi of the  Whole Mars Catalog . Enjoy! Show Notes * Official links *  Website ,  Paper *  GitHub  ( Llama 2 commit ) *  Azure Partnership *  Use policy ,  Statement of Support for Open Approach * Where to try * Llama2.ai ( source ),  Perplexity Llama Chat *  Live playground/API on Replicate ,  deploy all versions on Baseten *  https://huggingface.co/spaces/ysharma/Explore_llamav2_with_TGI ¬† * Dev ports -  simonw llm-replicate , ggml using llama.cpp ( 7B ,  13B ) or  pinokio ,¬†  ollama ,¬† Core ML port * Timeline * 24 Feb -  LLaMA 1 announced * 6 May -  our No Moats podcast  - first mention of Zuck opening up Llama * 14 July -  Llama 2 leaked * 18 July - Llama 2 announced * Community notes *  Nathan‚Äôs research paper recap *  638 LOC, 4 dependencies * Usage restrictions -  MAU restriction ,  derivative models *  Grouped Query Attention *  System prompt *  2 trillion token dataset * >$20m price tag ( rlhf ,  jimfan ),¬† * Separate models for safety and helpfulness ( jimfan ) *  Mistral AI founders left out of paper * Interesting fails:
